built with pdoc

graphlearning.ssl

Semi-Supervised Learning

This module implements many graph-based semi-supervised learning algorithms in an objected-oriented fashion, similar to sklearn. The usage is similar for all algorithms. Below, we give some high-level examples of how to use this module. There are also examples for some individual functions, given in the documentation below.

Two Moons Example

Semi-supervised learning on the two-moons dataset: ssl_twomoons.py.

import numpy as np
import graphlearning as gl
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import sklearn.datasets as datasets

X,labels = datasets.make_moons(n_samples=500,noise=0.1)
W = gl.weightmatrix.knn(X,10)

train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=5)
train_labels = labels[train_ind]

model = gl.ssl.laplace(W)
pred_labels = model.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels)

accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, labels, train_ind)   
print("Accuracy: %.2f%%"%accuracy)

plt.scatter(X[:,0],X[:,1], c=pred_labels)
plt.scatter(X[train_ind,0],X[train_ind,1], c='r')
plt.show()
Handwritten digit classification

Laplace and Poisson learning on MNIST at 1 label per class: ssl_mnist.py.

import graphlearning as gl

labels = gl.datasets.load('mnist', labels_only=True)
W = gl.weightmatrix.knn('mnist', 10, metric='vae')

num_train_per_class = 1
train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=num_train_per_class)
train_labels = labels[train_ind]

models = [gl.ssl.laplace(W), gl.ssl.poisson(W)]

for model in models:
    pred_labels = model.fit_predict(train_ind,train_labels)
    accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, labels, train_ind)
    print(model.name + ': %.2f%%'%accuracy)
Comparing different methods

The ssl module contains functions for running large scale experiments, with parallel processing, to compare many different semi-supervised learning algorithms at different label rates and with different, randomly chosen, training data. The package includes functions to automatically create LaTeX tables and plots comparing accuracy or test error. This example compares several methods over 100 randomized trials: ssl_trials.py.

import graphlearning as gl

dataset = 'mnist'
metric = 'vae' 
k = 10 

W = gl.weightmatrix.knn(dataset, k, metric=metric)
D = gl.weightmatrix.knn(dataset, k, metric=metric, kernel='distance')

labels = gl.datasets.load(dataset, metric=metric, labels_only=True)
trainsets = gl.trainsets.load(dataset)

model_list = [gl.ssl.graph_nearest_neighbor(D),
              gl.ssl.laplace(W),
              gl.ssl.laplace(W, reweighting='wnll'), 
              gl.ssl.laplace(W, reweighting='poisson'),
              gl.ssl.poisson(W, solver='gradient_descent')]

tag = dataset + '_' + metric + '_k%d'%k
for model in model_list:
    model.ssl_trials(trainsets, labels, num_cores=20, tag=tag)

gl.ssl.accuracy_table(model_list, tag=tag, savefile='SSL_'+dataset+'.tex', title="SSL Comparison: "+dataset)
gl.ssl.accuracy_plot(model_list, tag=tag, title='SSL')
Class Priors

Prior information about relative class sizes can be used to improve performance: ssl_classpriors.py.

import graphlearning as gl

labels = gl.datasets.load('mnist', labels_only=True)
W = gl.weightmatrix.knn('mnist', 10, metric='vae')

num_train_per_class = 1
train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=num_train_per_class)
train_labels = labels[train_ind]

class_priors = gl.utils.class_priors(labels)
model = gl.ssl.laplace(W, class_priors=class_priors)
model.fit(train_ind,train_labels)

pred_labels = model.predict(ignore_class_priors=True)
accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(labels,pred_labels,train_ind)
print(model.name + ' without class priors: %.2f%%'%accuracy)

pred_labels = model.predict()
accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(labels,pred_labels,train_ind)
print(model.name + ' with class priors: %.2f%%'%accuracy)

   7Below, we give some high-level examples of how to use this module. There are also examples for some
   8individual functions, given in the documentation below.

  55Comparing different methods
  56-----------
  57The `ssl` module contains functions for running large scale experiments, with parallel processing,
  58to compare many different semi-supervised learning algorithms at different label rates
  59and with different, randomly chosen, training data. The package includes functions to automatically
  60create LaTeX tables and plots comparing accuracy or test error. This example compares several methods over 100 
  61randomized trials: [ssl_trials.py](https://github.com/jwcalder/GraphLearning/blob/master/examples/ssl_trials.py).
  62```py
  63import graphlearning as gl
  64
  65dataset = 'mnist'
  66metric = 'vae' 
  67k = 10 
  68
  69W = gl.weightmatrix.knn(dataset, k, metric=metric)
  70D = gl.weightmatrix.knn(dataset, k, metric=metric, kernel='distance')
  71
  72labels = gl.datasets.load(dataset, metric=metric, labels_only=True)
  73trainsets = gl.trainsets.load(dataset)
  74
  75model_list = [gl.ssl.graph_nearest_neighbor(D),
  76              gl.ssl.laplace(W),
  77              gl.ssl.laplace(W, reweighting='wnll'), 
  78              gl.ssl.laplace(W, reweighting='poisson'),
  79              gl.ssl.poisson(W, solver='gradient_descent')]
  80
  81tag = dataset + '_' + metric + '_k%d'%k
  82for model in model_list:
  83    model.ssl_trials(trainsets, labels, num_cores=20, tag=tag)
  84
  85gl.ssl.accuracy_table(model_list, tag=tag, savefile='SSL_'+dataset+'.tex', title="SSL Comparison: "+dataset)
  86gl.ssl.accuracy_plot(model_list, tag=tag, title='SSL')
  87```
  88Class Priors
  89-----------
  90Prior information about relative class sizes can be used to improve performance: [ssl_classpriors.py](https://github.com/jwcalder/GraphLearning/blob/master/examples/ssl_classpriors.py).
  91```py
  92import graphlearning as gl
  93
  94labels = gl.datasets.load('mnist', labels_only=True)
  95W = gl.weightmatrix.knn('mnist', 10, metric='vae')
  96
  97num_train_per_class = 1
  98train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=num_train_per_class)
  99train_labels = labels[train_ind]
 100
 101class_priors = gl.utils.class_priors(labels)
 102model = gl.ssl.laplace(W, class_priors=class_priors)
 103model.fit(train_ind,train_labels)
 104
 105pred_labels = model.predict(ignore_class_priors=True)
 106accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(labels,pred_labels,train_ind)
 107print(model.name + ' without class priors: %.2f%%'%accuracy)
 108
 109pred_labels = model.predict()
 110accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(labels,pred_labels,train_ind)
 111print(model.name + ' with class priors: %.2f%%'%accuracy)
 112```
 113"""
 114import numpy as np
 115from scipy import sparse
 116from abc import ABCMeta, abstractmethod
 117import multiprocessing
 118from joblib import Parallel, delayed
 119import sys, os, datetime, matplotlib
 120import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 121
 122
 123from . import utils 
 124from . import graph
 125
 126
 127
 128#Directories
 129results_dir = os.path.join(os.getcwd(),'results')
 130
 131class ssl:
 132    __metaclass__ = ABCMeta
 133
 134    def __init__(self, W, class_priors):
 135        if W is None:
 136            self.graph = None
 137        else:
 138            self.set_graph(W)
 139        self.prob = None
 140        self.fitted = False
 141        self.name = ''
 142        self.accuracy_filename = ''
 143        self.requires_eig = False
 144        self.onevsrest = False
 145        self.similarity = True
 146        self.class_priors = class_priors
 147        if self.class_priors is not None:
 148            self.class_priors = self.class_priors / np.sum(self.class_priors)
 149        self.weights = 1
 150        self.class_priors_error = 1
 151
 152    def set_graph(self, W):
 153        """Set Graph
 154        ===================
 155
 156        Sets the graph object for semi-supervised learning.
 157
 158        Implements 3 different solvers, spectral, gradient_descent, and conjugate_gradient. 
 159        GPU acceleration is available for gradient descent. See [1] for details.
 160
 161        Parameters
 162        ----------
 163        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
 164            Weight matrix representing the graph.
 165        """
 166
 167        if type(W) == graph.graph:
 168            self.graph = W
 169        else:
 170            self.graph = graph.graph(W)
 171
 172    def volume_label_projection(self):
 173        """Volume label projection
 174        ======
 175    
 176        Projects class probabilities to labels while enforcing a constraint on 
 177        class priors (i.e., class volumes). Does not return anything, just modifies `self.weights`.
 178        
 179        Returns
 180        -------
 181        labels : numpy array (int)
 182            Predicted labels after volume correction.
 183        """
 184
 185        n = self.graph.num_nodes
 186        k = self.prob.shape[1]
 187        if type(self.weights) == int:
 188            self.weights = np.ones((k,))
 189
 190        #Time step
 191        dt = 0.1
 192        if self.similarity:
 193            dt *= -1
 194
 195        #np.set_printoptions(formatter={'float': lambda x: "{0:0.3f}".format(x)})
 196        i = 0
 197        err = 1
 198        while i < 1e4 and err > 1e-3:
 199            i += 1
 200            class_size = np.mean(utils.labels_to_onehot(self.predict()),axis=0)
 201            #print(class_size-self.class_priors)
 202            grad = class_size - self.class_priors
 203            err = np.max(np.absolute(grad))
 204            self.weights += dt*grad
 205            self.weights = self.weights/self.weights[0]
 206
 207        self.class_priors_error = err
 208
 209        return self.predict()
 210
 211    def get_accuracy_filename(self):
 212        """Get accuracy filename
 213        ========
 214
 215        Returns name of the file that will store the accuracy results for `ssl_trials.py`.
 216
 217        Returns
 218        -------
 219        fname : str
 220            Accuracy filename.
 221        """
 222
 223        fname = self.accuracy_filename
 224        if self.class_priors is not None:
 225            fname += '_classpriors'
 226        fname += '_accuracy.csv'
 227        return fname
 228
 229
 230    def predict(self, ignore_class_priors=False):
 231        """Predict
 232        ========
 233
 234        Makes label predictions based on the probabilities computed by `fit()`.
 235        Will use a volume label projection if `class_priors` were given, to ensure 
 236        the number of nodes predicted in each class is correct.
 237        
 238        Parameters
 239        ----------
 240        ignore_class_priors : bool (optional), default=False
 241            Used to disable the volume constrained label decision, when `class_priors` has been provided. 
 242
 243        Returns
 244        -------
 245        pred_labels : (int) numpy array
 246            Predicted labels as integers for all datapoints in the graph.
 247        """
 248
 249        if self.fitted == False:
 250            sys.exit('Model has not been fitted yet.')
 251
 252        if ignore_class_priors:
 253            w = 1
 254        else:
 255            w = self.weights
 256
 257        scores = self.prob - np.min(self.prob)
 258        scores = scores/np.max(scores)
 259
 260        #Check if scores are similarity or distance
 261        if self.similarity:
 262            pred_labels = np.argmax(scores*w,axis=1)
 263        else: #Then distances
 264            pred_labels = np.argmin(scores*w,axis=1)
 265
 266        return pred_labels 
 267
 268    def fit_predict(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 269        """Fit and predict
 270        ======
 271
 272        Calls fit() and predict() sequentially.
 273
 274        Parameters
 275        ----------
 276        train_ind : numpy array, int
 277            Indicies of training points.
 278        train_labels : numpy array, int
 279            Training labels as integers \\(0,1,\\dots,k-1\\) for \\(k\\) classes.
 280        all_labels : numpy array, int (optional)
 281            True labels for all datapoints.
 282
 283        Returns
 284        -------
 285        pred_labels : (int) numpy array
 286            Predicted labels as integers for all datapoints in the graph.
 287        """
 288
 289        self.fit(train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=all_labels)
 290        return self.predict()
 291
 292    def ssl_trials(self, trainsets, labels, num_cores=1, tag='', save_results=True, overwrite=False, num_trials=-1):
 293        """Semi-supervised learning trials
 294        ===================
 295
 296        Runs a semi-supervised learning algorithm on a list of training sets,
 297        recording the label rates and saves the results to a csv file in the
 298        local folder results/. The filename is controlled by the member function
 299        model.get_accuracy_filename(). The trial will abort if the accuracy result
 300        file already exists, unless `overwrite=True`.
 301
 302        Parameters
 303        ----------
 304        trainsets : list of numpy arrays
 305            Collection of training sets to run semi-supervised learning on. This is the output
 306            of `graphlearning.trainsets.generate` or `graphlearning.trainsets.load`.
 307        labels : numpy array (int)
 308            Integer array of labels for entire dataset.
 309        num_cores : int
 310            Number of cores to use for parallel processing over trials
 311        tag : str (optional), default=''
 312            An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
 313        save_results : bool (optional), default=True
 314            Whether to save results to csv file or just print to the screen.
 315        overwrite : bool (optional), default = False
 316            Whether to overwrite existing results file, if found. If `overwrite=False`, 
 317            `save_results=True`, and the results file is found, the trial is aborted.
 318        num_trials: int (optional), defualt = -1
 319            Number of trials. Any negative number runs all trials.
 320        """
 321
 322        if num_trials > 0:
 323            trainsets = trainsets[:num_trials]
 324
 325        #Print name
 326        print('\nModel: '+self.name)
 327
 328        if save_results:
 329            if not os.path.exists(results_dir):
 330                os.makedirs(results_dir)
 331
 332            outfile = os.path.join(results_dir, tag+self.get_accuracy_filename())
 333            if (not overwrite) and os.path.exists(outfile):
 334                print('Aborting: SSL trial already completed, and overwrite is False.')
 335                return
 336            f = open(outfile,"w")
 337            #now = datetime.datetime.now()
 338            #f.write("Date/Time, "+now.strftime("%Y-%m-%d_%H:%M")+"\n")
 339            if self.class_priors is None:
 340                f.write('Number of labels,Accuracy\n')
 341            else:
 342                f.write('Number of labels,Accuracy,Accuracy with class priors,Class priors error\n')
 343            f.close()
 344
 345        if save_results:
 346            print('Results File: '+outfile)
 347
 348        if self.class_priors is None:
 349            print('\nNumber of labels,Accuracy')
 350        else:
 351            print('\nNumber of labels,Accuracy,Accuracy with class priors,Class priors error')
 352
 353        #Trial run to trigger eigensolvers, when needed
 354        if self.requires_eig:
 355            pred_labels = self.fit_predict(trainsets[0], labels[trainsets[0]])
 356     
 357        def one_trial(train_ind):
 358
 359            #Number of labels
 360            num_train = len(train_ind)
 361            train_labels = labels[train_ind]
 362
 363            #Run semi-supervised learning
 364            pred_labels = self.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels)
 365
 366            #Compute accuracy
 367            accuracy = ssl_accuracy(pred_labels,labels,train_ind)
 368
 369            #If class priors were provided, check accuracy without priors
 370            if self.class_priors is not None:
 371                pred_labels = self.predict(ignore_class_priors=True)
 372                accuracy_without_priors = ssl_accuracy(pred_labels,labels,train_ind)
 373            
 374            #Print to terminal
 375            if self.class_priors is None:
 376                print("%d" % num_train + ",%.2f" % accuracy)
 377            else:
 378                print("%d,%.2f,%.2f,%.5f" % (num_train,accuracy_without_priors,accuracy,self.class_priors_error))
 379
 380            #Write to file
 381            if save_results:
 382                f = open(outfile,"a+")
 383                if self.class_priors is None:
 384                    f.write("%d" % num_train + ",%.2f\n" % accuracy)
 385                else:
 386                    f.write("%d,%.2f,%.2f,%.5f\n" % (num_train,accuracy_without_priors,accuracy,
 387                                                                            self.class_priors_error))
 388                f.close()
 389
 390        num_cores = min(multiprocessing.cpu_count(),num_cores)
 391
 392        if num_cores == 1:
 393            for train_ind in trainsets:
 394                one_trial(train_ind)
 395        else:
 396            Parallel(n_jobs=num_cores)(delayed(one_trial)(train_ind) for train_ind in trainsets)
 397
 398    def trials_statistics(self, tag=''):
 399        """Trials statistics
 400        ===================
 401
 402        Loads accuracy scores from each trial from csv files created by `ssl_trials`
 403        and returns summary statistics (mean and standard deviation of accuracy).
 404
 405        Parameters
 406        ----------
 407        tag : str (optional), default=''
 408            An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
 409
 410        Returns
 411        -------
 412        num_train : numpy array
 413            Number of training examples in each label rate experiment.
 414        acc_mean : numpy array
 415            Mean accuracy over all trials in each experiment.
 416        acc_stddev : numpy array
 417            Standard deviation of accuracy over all trials in each experiment.
 418        num_trials : int
 419            Number of trials for each label rate.
 420        """
 421
 422        accuracy_filename = os.path.join(results_dir, tag+self.get_accuracy_filename())
 423        X = utils.csvread(accuracy_filename)
 424        num_train = np.unique(X[:,0])
 425
 426        acc_mean = []
 427        acc_stddev = []
 428        for n in num_train:
 429            Y = X[X[:,0]==n,1:]
 430            acc_mean += [np.mean(Y,axis=0)]
 431            acc_stddev += [np.std(Y,axis=0)]
 432
 433        num_trials = int(len(X[:,0])/len(num_train))
 434        acc_mean = np.array(acc_mean)
 435        acc_stddev = np.array(acc_stddev)
 436        return num_train, acc_mean, acc_stddev, num_trials
 437
 438   
 439    def fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 440        """Fit
 441        ======
 442
 443        Solves graph-based learning problem, computing the probability 
 444        that each node belongs to each class. If `all_labels` is provided, 
 445        then the solver operates in verbose mode, printing out accuracy
 446        at each iteration.
 447
 448        Parameters
 449        ----------
 450        train_ind : numpy array, int
 451            Indicies of training points.
 452        train_labels : numpy array, int
 453            Training labels as integers \\(0,1,\\dots,k-1\\) for \\(k\\) classes.
 454        all_labels : numpy array, int (optional)
 455            True labels for all datapoints.
 456
 457        Returns
 458        -------
 459        u : (n,k) numpy array, float
 460            Probabilities computed by graph-based learning for each node and each class.
 461        """
 462
 463        if self.graph is None:
 464            sys.exit('SSL object has no graph. Use graph.set_graph() to provide a graph for SSL.')
 465
 466        self.fitted = True
 467
 468        #If a one-vs-rest classifier
 469        if self.onevsrest:
 470            unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
 471            num_labels = len(unique_labels)
 472            self.prob = np.zeros((self.graph.num_nodes,num_labels))
 473            for i,l in enumerate(unique_labels):
 474                self.prob[:,i] = self._fit(train_ind, train_labels==l)
 475        else:
 476            self.prob = self._fit(train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=all_labels)
 477
 478        if self.class_priors is not None:
 479            self.volume_label_projection()
 480
 481        return self.prob
 482
 483    @abstractmethod
 484    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 485        """Internal Fit Function
 486        ======
 487
 488        Internal fit function that any ssl object must override. If `self.onevsrest=True` then
 489        `train_labels` are binary in the one-vs-rest framework, and `_fit` must return
 490        a scalar numpy array. Otherwise the labels are integer and `_fit` must return an (n,k)
 491        numpy array of probabilities, where `k` is the number of classes.
 492
 493        Parameters
 494        ----------
 495        train_ind : numpy array, int
 496            Indicies of training points.
 497        train_labels : numpy array, int
 498            Training labels as integers \\(0,1,\\dots,k-1\\) for \\(k\\) classes, or binary
 499            if `self.onevsrest=True`.
 500        all_labels : numpy array, int (optional)
 501            True labels for all datapoints.
 502
 503        Returns
 504        -------
 505        u : numpy array, float
 506            (n,k) array of probabilities computed by graph-based learning for each node and each class, unless
 507            `self.onevsrest=True`, in which case it is a length n numpy array of probablities for the current 
 508            class.
 509        """
 510        raise NotImplementedError("Must override _fit")
 511
 512
 513class poisson(ssl):
 514    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, solver='conjugate_gradient', p=1, use_cuda=False, min_iter=50, max_iter=1000, tol=1e-3, spectral_cutoff=10):
 515        """Poisson Learning
 516        ===================
 517
 518        Semi-supervised learning via the solution of the Poisson equation 
 519        \\[L^p u = \\sum_{j=1}^m \\delta_j(y_j - \\overline{y})^T,\\]
 520        where \\(L=D-W\\) is the combinatorial graph Laplacian, 
 521        \\(y_j\\) are the label vectors, \\(\\overline{y} = \\frac{1}{m}\\sum_{i=1}^m y_j\\) 
 522        is the average label vector, \\(m\\) is the number of training points, and 
 523        \\(\\delta_j\\) are standard basis vectors. See the reference for more details.
 524
 525        Implements 3 different solvers, spectral, gradient_descent, and conjugate_gradient. 
 526        GPU acceleration is available for gradient descent. See [1] for details.
 527
 528        Parameters
 529        ----------
 530        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
 531            Weight matrix representing the graph.
 532        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
 533            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
 534            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
 535            nodes in each class.
 536        solver : {'spectral', 'conjugate_gradient', 'gradient_descent'} (optional), default='conjugate_gradient'
 537            Choice of solver for Poisson learning.
 538        p : int (optional), default=1
 539            Power for Laplacian, can be any positive real number. Solver will default to 'spectral' if p!=1.
 540        use_cuda : bool (optional), default=False
 541            Whether to use GPU acceleration for gradient descent solver.
 542        min_iter : int (optional), default=50
 543            Minimum number of iterations of gradient descent before checking stopping condition.
 544        max_iter : int (optional), default=1000
 545            Maximum number of iterations of gradient descent.
 546        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
 547            Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
 548        spectral_cutoff : int (optional), default=10
 549            Number of eigenvectors to use for spectral solver.
 550
 551        Examples
 552        --------
 553        Poisson learning works on directed (i.e., nonsymmetric) graphs with the gradient descent solver: [poisson_directed.py](https://github.com/jwcalder/GraphLearning/blob/master/examples/poisson_directed.py).
 554        ```py
 555        import numpy as np
 556        import graphlearning as gl
 557        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
 558        import sklearn.datasets as datasets
 559
 560        X,labels = datasets.make_moons(n_samples=500,noise=0.1)
 561        W = gl.weightmatrix.knn(X,10,symmetrize=False)
 562
 563        train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=5)
 564        train_labels = labels[train_ind]
 565
 566        model = gl.ssl.poisson(W, solver='gradient_descent')
 567        pred_labels = model.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels)
 568
 569        accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, labels, train_ind)   
 570        print("Accuracy: %.2f%%"%accuracy)
 571
 572        plt.scatter(X[:,0],X[:,1], c=pred_labels)
 573        plt.scatter(X[train_ind,0],X[train_ind,1], c='r')
 574        plt.show()
 575        ```
 576
 577        Reference
 578        ---------
 579        [1] J. Calder, B. Cook, M. Thorpe, D. Slepcev. [Poisson Learning: Graph Based Semi-Supervised
 580        Learning at Very Low Label Rates.](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v119/calder20a.html), 
 581        Proceedings of the 37th International Conference on Machine Learning, PMLR 119:1306-1316, 2020.
 582        """
 583        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
 584        if solver not in ['conjugate_gradient', 'spectral', 'gradient_descent']:
 585            sys.exit("Invalid Poisson solver")
 586        self.solver = solver
 587        self.p = p
 588        if p != 1:
 589            self.solver = 'spectral'
 590        self.use_cuda = use_cuda
 591        self.min_iter = min_iter
 592        self.max_iter = max_iter
 593        self.tol = tol
 594        self.spectral_cutoff = spectral_cutoff
 595
 596        #Setup accuracy filename
 597        fname = '_poisson' 
 598        if self.p != 1:
 599            fname += '_p%.2f'%p
 600        if self.solver == 'spectral':
 601            fname += '_N%d'%self.spectral_cutoff
 602            self.requries_eig = True
 603        self.accuracy_filename = fname
 604
 605        #Setup Algorithm name
 606        self.name = 'Poisson Learning'
 607
 608    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 609
 610        n = self.graph.num_nodes
 611        unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
 612        k = len(unique_labels)
 613        
 614        #Zero out diagonal for faster convergence
 615        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
 616        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
 617        G = graph.graph(W)
 618
 619        #Poisson source term
 620        onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
 621        source = np.zeros((n, onehot.shape[1]))
 622        source[train_ind] = onehot - np.mean(onehot, axis=0)
 623        
 624        if self.solver == 'conjugate_gradient':  #Conjugate gradient solver
 625
 626            L = G.laplacian(normalization='normalized')
 627            D = G.degree_matrix(p=-0.5)
 628            u = utils.conjgrad(L, D*source, tol=self.tol)
 629            u = D*u
 630
 631        elif self.solver == "gradient_descent":
 632
 633            #Setup matrices
 634            D = G.degree_matrix(p=-1)
 635            P = D*W.transpose()
 636            Db = D*source
 637
 638            #Invariant distribution
 639            v = np.zeros(n)
 640            v[train_ind]=1
 641            v = v/np.sum(v)
 642            deg = G.degree_vector()
 643            vinf = deg/np.sum(deg)
 644            RW = W.transpose()*D
 645            u = np.zeros((n,k))
 646
 647            #Number of iterations
 648            T = 0
 649            if self.use_cuda:
 650
 651                import torch 
 652
 653                Pt = utils.torch_sparse(P).cuda()
 654                ut = torch.from_numpy(u).float().cuda()
 655                Dbt = torch.from_numpy(Db).float().cuda()
 656
 657                while (T < self.min_iter or np.max(np.absolute(v-vinf)) > 1/n) and (T < self.max_iter):
 658                    ut = torch.sparse.addmm(Dbt,Pt,ut)
 659                    v = RW*v
 660                    T = T + 1
 661
 662                #Transfer to CPU and convert to numpy
 663                u = ut.cpu().numpy()
 664
 665            else: #Use CPU
 666
 667                while (T < self.min_iter or np.max(np.absolute(v-vinf)) > 1/n) and (T < self.max_iter):
 668                    u = Db + P*u
 669                    v = RW*v
 670                    T = T + 1
 671
 672                    #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
 673                    if all_labels is not None:
 674                        self.prob = u
 675                        labels = self.predict()
 676                        acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
 677                        print('%d,Accuracy = %.2f'%(T,acc))
 678                
 679        #Use spectral solver
 680        elif self.solver == 'spectral':
 681
 682            vals, vecs = G.eigen_decomp(normalization='randomwalk', k=self.spectral_cutoff+1)
 683            V = vecs[:,1:]
 684            vals = vals[1:]
 685            if self.p != 1:
 686                vals = vals**self.p
 687            L = sparse.spdiags(1/vals, 0, self.spectral_cutoff, self.spectral_cutoff)
 688            u = V@(L@(V.T@source))
 689
 690        else:
 691            sys.exit("Invalid Poisson solver " + self.solver)
 692
 693        return u
 694
 695class poisson_mbo(ssl):
 696    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, solver='conjugate_gradient', use_cuda=False, min_iter=50, max_iter=1000, tol=1e-3, spectral_cutoff=10, Ns=40, mu=1, T=20):
 697        """PoissonMBO 
 698        ===================
 699
 700        Semi-supervised learning via Poisson MBO method [1]. class_priors must be provided.
 701
 702        Parameters
 703        ----------
 704        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
 705            Weight matrix representing the graph.
 706        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
 707            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). 
 708        solver : {'spectral', 'conjugate_gradient', 'gradient_descent'} (optional), default='conjugate_gradient'
 709            Choice of solver for Poisson learning.
 710        use_cuda : bool (optional), default=False
 711            Whether to use GPU acceleration for gradient descent solver.
 712        min_iter : int (optional), default=50
 713            Minimum number of iterations of gradient descent before checking stopping condition.
 714        max_iter : int (optional), default=1000
 715            Maximum number of iterations of gradient descent.
 716        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
 717            Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
 718        spectral_cutoff : int (optional), default=10
 719            Number of eigenvectors to use for spectral solver.
 720        Ns : int (optional), default=40
 721            Number of inner iterations in PoissonMBO.
 722        mu : float (optional), default=1
 723            Fidelity parameter.
 724        T : int (optional), default=20
 725            Number of MBO iterations.
 726        
 727        Example
 728        -------
 729        Running PoissonMBO on MNIST at 1 label per class: [poisson_mbo.py](https://github.com/jwcalder/GraphLearning/blob/master/examples/poisson_mbo.py).
 730        ```py
 731        import graphlearning as gl
 732
 733        labels = gl.datasets.load('mnist', labels_only=True)
 734        W = gl.weightmatrix.knn('mnist', 10, metric='vae')
 735
 736        num_train_per_class = 1
 737        train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=num_train_per_class)
 738        train_labels = labels[train_ind]
 739
 740        class_priors = gl.utils.class_priors(labels)
 741        model = gl.ssl.poisson_mbo(W, class_priors)
 742        pred_labels = model.fit_predict(train_ind,train_labels,all_labels=labels)
 743
 744        accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(labels,pred_labels,train_ind)
 745        print(model.name + ': %.2f%%'%accuracy)
 746        ```
 747        Reference
 748        ---------
 749        [1] J. Calder, B. Cook, M. Thorpe, D. Slepcev. [Poisson Learning: Graph Based Semi-Supervised
 750        Learning at Very Low Label Rates.](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v119/calder20a.html), 
 751        Proceedings of the 37th International Conference on Machine Learning, PMLR 119:1306-1316, 2020.
 752        """
 753        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
 754
 755        self.poisson_model = poisson(W, solver=solver, use_cuda=use_cuda, min_iter=min_iter, 
 756                                     max_iter=max_iter, tol=tol, spectral_cutoff=spectral_cutoff)
 757
 758        self.Ns = Ns
 759        self.mu = mu
 760        self.T = T
 761        self.use_cuda = use_cuda
 762
 763        #Setup accuracy filename
 764        fname = '_poisson_mbo' 
 765        if solver == 'spectral':
 766            fname += '_N%d'%spectral_cutoff
 767            self.requries_eig = True
 768        fname += '_Ns_%d_mu_%.2f_T_%d'%(Ns,mu,T)
 769        self.accuracy_filename = fname
 770
 771        #Setup Algorithm name
 772        self.name = 'Poisson MBO' 
 773
 774    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 775
 776        #Short forms
 777        Ns = self.Ns
 778        mu = self.mu
 779        T = self.T
 780        use_cuda = self.use_cuda
 781
 782        n = self.graph.num_nodes
 783        unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
 784        k = len(unique_labels)
 785
 786        #Zero out diagonal for faster convergence
 787        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
 788        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
 789        G = graph.graph(W)
 790        
 791        #Poisson source term
 792        onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
 793        source = np.zeros((n, onehot.shape[1]))
 794        source[train_ind] = onehot - np.mean(onehot, axis=0)
 795
 796        #Initialize via Poisson learning
 797        labels = self.poisson_model.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=all_labels)
 798        u = utils.labels_to_onehot(labels)
 799
 800        #Time step for stability
 801        dt = 1/np.max(G.degree_vector())
 802
 803        #Precompute some things
 804        P = sparse.identity(n) - dt*G.laplacian()
 805        Db = mu*dt*source
 806
 807        if use_cuda:
 808            import torch
 809            Pt = utils.torch_sparse(P).cuda()
 810            Dbt = torch.from_numpy(Db).float().cuda()
 811
 812        for i in range(T):
 813
 814            #Heat equation step
 815            if use_cuda:
 816
 817                #Put on GPU and run heat equation
 818                ut = torch.from_numpy(u).float().cuda()
 819                for j in range(Ns):
 820                    ut = torch.sparse.addmm(Dbt,Pt,ut)
 821
 822                #Put back on CPU
 823                u = ut.cpu().numpy()
 824             
 825            else: #Use CPU 
 826                for j in range(Ns):
 827                    u = P*u + Db
 828
 829            #Projection step
 830            self.prob = u
 831            labels = self.volume_label_projection()
 832            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(labels)
 833
 834            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
 835            if all_labels is not None:
 836                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
 837                print('%d, Accuracy = %.2f'%(i,acc))
 838
 839        return u
 840
 841class volume_mbo(ssl):
 842    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, temperature=0.1, volume_constraint=0.5):
 843        """Volume MBO
 844        ===================
 845
 846        Semi-supervised learning with the VolumeMBO method [1]. class_priors must be provided.
 847
 848        Parameters
 849        ----------
 850        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
 851            Weight matrix representing the graph.
 852        class_priors : numpy array
 853            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). 
 854        temperature : float (optional), default=0.1
 855            Temperature for volume constrained MBO.
 856        volume_constraint : float (optional), default=0.5
 857            The number of points in each class is constrained to be a mulitple \\(\\lambda\\) of the true
 858            class size, where 
 859            \\[ \\text{volume_constraint} \\leq \\lambda \\leq 2-\\text{volume_constraint}.\\]
 860            Setting `volume_constraint=1` yields the tightest constraint.
 861
 862        References
 863        ----------
 864        [1] M. Jacobs, E. Merkurjev, and S. Esedoḡlu. [Auction dynamics: A volume constrained MBO scheme.](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021999117308033?casa_token=kNahPd2vu50AAAAA:uJQYQVnmMBV_oL0CG1UcOIulY4vhclMGTztm-jjAzy9Lns7rtoOnKs4iyvLOjKXaHU-D6qrQJT4) Journal of Computational Physics 354:288-310, 2018. 
 865        """
 866        super().__init__(W, None)
 867
 868        if class_priors is None:
 869            sys.exit("Class priors must be provided for Volume MBO.")
 870        self.class_counts = (self.graph.num_nodes*class_priors).astype(int)
 871        self.temperature = temperature
 872        self.volume_constraint = volume_constraint
 873
 874        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
 875        self.accuracy_filename = '_volume_mbo_temp_%.2f_vol_%.2f'%(temperature,volume_constraint)
 876        self.name = 'Volume MBO (T=%.2f, V=%.2f)'%(temperature,volume_constraint)
 877
 878
 879    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 880
 881        #Import c extensions
 882        from . import cextensions
 883
 884        n = self.graph.num_nodes
 885
 886        #Set diagonal entries to zero
 887        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
 888        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
 889        G = graph.graph(W)
 890
 891        #Set up graph for C-code
 892        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
 893        u = np.zeros((n,))
 894        WI,WJ,WV = sparse.find(W)
 895
 896        #Type casting and memory blocking
 897        u = np.ascontiguousarray(u,dtype=np.int32)
 898        WI = np.ascontiguousarray(WI,dtype=np.int32)
 899        WJ = np.ascontiguousarray(WJ,dtype=np.int32)
 900        WV = np.ascontiguousarray(WV,dtype=np.float32)
 901        train_ind = np.ascontiguousarray(train_ind,dtype=np.int32)
 902        train_labels = np.ascontiguousarray(train_labels,dtype=np.int32)
 903        ClassCounts = np.ascontiguousarray(self.class_counts,dtype=np.int32)
 904
 905        cextensions.volume_mbo(u,WI,WJ,WV,train_ind,train_labels,ClassCounts,k,1.0,self.temperature,self.volume_constraint)
 906
 907        #Set given labels and convert to vector format
 908        u[train_ind] = train_labels
 909        u = utils.labels_to_onehot(u)
 910        return u
 911
 912class multiclass_mbo(ssl):
 913    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, Ns=6, T=10, dt=0.15, mu=50, num_eig=50):
 914        """Multiclass MBO
 915        ===================
 916
 917        Semi-supervised learning via the Multiclass MBO method [1].
 918
 919        Parameters
 920        ----------
 921        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
 922            Weight matrix representing the graph.
 923        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
 924            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
 925            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
 926            nodes in each class.
 927        Ns : int (optional), default=6
 928            Number of inner iterations.
 929        T : int (optional), default=10
 930            Number of outer iterations.
 931        dt : float (optional), default=0.15
 932            Time step.
 933        mu : float (optional), default=50
 934            Fidelity penalty.
 935        num_eig : int (optional), default=300
 936            Number of eigenvectors.
 937        
 938        References
 939        ---------
 940        [1] C. Garcia-Cardona, E. Merkurjev, A.L. Bertozzi, A. Flenner, and A.G. Percus. [Multiclass data segmentation using diffuse interface methods on graphs.](http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.743.9516&rep=rep1&type=pdf) IEEE transactions on pattern analysis and machine intelligence, 36(8), 1600-1613, 2014.
 941        """
 942        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
 943
 944        self.Ns = Ns
 945        self.T = T
 946        self.dt = dt
 947        self.mu = mu
 948        self.num_eig = num_eig
 949        self.requires_eig = True
 950
 951        #Setup accuracy filename
 952        self.accuracy_filename = '_multiclass_mbo_Ns_%d_T_%d_dt_%.3f_mu_%.2f'%(Ns,T,dt,mu)
 953        self.name = 'Multiclass MBO'
 954
 955
 956    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 957
 958        #Shorten names
 959        Ns = self.Ns
 960        T = self.T
 961        dt = self.dt
 962        mu = self.mu
 963        num_eig = self.num_eig
 964
 965        #Basic parameters
 966        n = self.graph.num_nodes
 967        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
 968
 969        #Spectral decomposition
 970        eigvals, X = self.graph.eigen_decomp(normalization='normalized', k=self.num_eig)
 971
 972        #Form matrices
 973        V = np.diag(1/(1 + (dt/Ns)*eigvals)) 
 974        Y = X@V
 975        Xt = np.transpose(X)
 976
 977        #Random initial labeling
 978        u = np.random.rand(k,n)
 979        u = utils.labels_to_onehot(np.argmax(u,axis=0)).T
 980        u[:,train_ind] = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels).T
 981
 982        #Indicator of train_ind
 983        J = np.zeros(n,)
 984        K = np.zeros(n,)
 985        J[train_ind] = 1
 986        K[train_ind] = train_labels
 987        K = utils.labels_to_onehot(K).T
 988
 989        for i in range(T):
 990            #Diffusion step
 991            for s in range(Ns):
 992                Z = (u - (dt/Ns)*mu*J*(u - K))@Y
 993                u = Z@Xt
 994                
 995            #Projection step
 996            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(np.argmax(u,axis=0)).T
 997
 998            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
 999            if all_labels is not None:
1000                self.prob = u.T
1001                labels = self.predict()
1002                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1003                print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1004
1005        return u.T
1006
1007class modularity_mbo(ssl):
1008    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, gamma=0.5, epsilon=1, lamb=1, T=20, Ns=5):
1009        """Modularity MBO
1010        ===================
1011
1012        Semi-supervised learning via the Modularity MBO method [1].
1013
1014        Parameters
1015        ----------
1016        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1017            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1018        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1019            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1020            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1021            nodes in each class.
1022        gamma : float (optional), default=0.5
1023            Parameter in algorithm.
1024        epsilon : float (optional), default=1
1025            Parameter in algorithm.
1026        lamb : float (optional), default=1
1027            Parameter in algorithm.
1028        T : int (optional), default=20
1029            Number of outer iterations.
1030        Ns : int (optional), default=5
1031            Number of inner iterations.
1032        
1033        References
1034        ---------
1035        [1] Z.M. Boyd, E. Bae, X.C. Tai, and A.L. Bertozzi. [Simplified energy landscape for modularity using total variation.](https://publications.ffi.no/nb/item/asset/dspace:4288/1619750.pdf) SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics, 78(5), 2439-2464, 2018.
1036        """
1037        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1038
1039        self.gamma = gamma
1040        self.epsilon = epsilon
1041        self.lamb = lamb
1042        self.requires_eig = True
1043        self.T = T
1044        self.Ns = Ns
1045
1046        #Setup accuracy filename
1047        self.accuracy_filename = '_modularity_mbo_gamma_%.2f_epsilon_%.2f_lamb_%.2f'%(gamma,epsilon,lamb)
1048        self.name = 'Modularity MBO'
1049
1050    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1051
1052        #Short form
1053        gamma = self.gamma
1054        eps = self.epsilon
1055        lamb = self.lamb
1056        T = self.T
1057        Ns = self.Ns
1058
1059        #One-hot initialization
1060        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1061        num_classes = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1062        train_onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1063        u = np.zeros((n,num_classes))
1064        u[train_ind,:] = train_onehot
1065
1066        #Spectral decomposition
1067        num_eig = 5*num_classes
1068        D, V = self.graph.eigen_decomp(normalization='combinatorial', k=num_eig, gamma=gamma)
1069
1070        #Time step selection
1071        deg = self.graph.degree_vector()
1072        dtlow = 0.15/((gamma+1)*np.max(deg))
1073        dthigh = np.log(np.linalg.norm(u)/eps)/D[0]
1074        dt = np.sqrt(dtlow*dthigh)
1075
1076        #Diffusion matrix
1077        P = sparse.spdiags(np.exp(-D*dt),0,num_eig,num_eig)@V.T
1078
1079        #Main MBO iterations
1080        for i in range(T):
1081
1082            #Diffusion 
1083            u = V@(P@u)
1084
1085            #Training labels
1086            if lamb > 0:
1087                for _ in range(Ns):
1088                    u[train_ind,:] -= (dt/Ns)*lamb*(u[train_ind,:] - train_onehot)
1089
1090            #Threshold to labels
1091            labels = np.argmax(u,axis=1)
1092            
1093            #Convert to 1-hot vectors
1094            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(labels)
1095
1096            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1097            if all_labels is not None:
1098                self.prob = u
1099                labels = self.predict()
1100                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1101                print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1102
1103        return u
1104
1105
1106class laplace(ssl):
1107    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, X=None, reweighting='none', normalization='combinatorial', 
1108                 tau=0, order=1, mean_shift=False, tol=1e-5, alpha=2, zeta=1e7, r=0.1):
1109        """Laplace Learning
1110        ===================
1111
1112        Semi-supervised learning via the solution of the Laplace equation
1113        \\[\\tau u_j + L^m u_j = 0, \\ \\ j \\geq m+1,\\]
1114        subject to \\(u_j = y_j\\) for \\(j=1,\\dots,m\\), where \\(L=D-W\\) is the 
1115        combinatorial graph Laplacian and \\(y_j\\) for \\(j=1,\\dots,m\\) are the 
1116        label vectors. Default order is m=1, and m > 1 corresponds to higher order Laplace Learning.
1117
1118        The original method was introduced in [1]. This class also implements reweighting 
1119        schemes `poisson` proposed in [2], `wnll` proposed in [3], and `properly`, proposed in [4].
1120        If `properly` is selected, the user must additionally provide the data features `X`.
1121
1122        Parameters
1123        ----------
1124        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1125            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1126        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1127            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1128            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1129            nodes in each class.
1130        X : numpy array (optional)
1131            Data features, used to construct the graph. This is required for the `properly` weighted 
1132            graph Laplacian method.
1133        normalization : {'combinatorial','randomwalk','normalized'} (optional), defualt='combinatorial'
1134            Normalization for the graph Laplacian.
1135        reweighting : {'none', 'wnll', 'poisson', 'properly'} (optional), default='none'
1136            Reweighting scheme for low label rate problems. If 'properly' is selected, the user
1137            must supply the data features `X`.
1138        tau : float or numpy array (optional), default=0
1139            Zeroth order term in Laplace equation. Can be a scalar or vector.
1140        order : integer (optional), default=1
1141            Power m for higher order Laplace learning. Currently only integers are allowed. 
1142        mean_shift : bool (optional), default=False
1143            Whether to shift output to mean zero.
1144        tol : float (optional), default=1e-5
1145            Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
1146        alpha : float (optional), default=2
1147            Parameter for `properly` reweighting.
1148        zeta : float (optional), default=1e7
1149            Parameter for `properly` reweighting.
1150        r : float (optional), default=0.1
1151            Radius for `properly` reweighting.
1152
1153        References
1154        ---------
1155        [1] X. Zhu, Z. Ghahramani, and J. D. Lafferty. [Semi-supervised learning using gaussian fields 
1156        and harmonic functions.](https://www.aaai.org/Papers/ICML/2003/ICML03-118.pdf) Proceedings 
1157        of the 20th International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML-03), 2003.
1158
1159        [2] J. Calder, B. Cook, M. Thorpe, D. Slepcev. [Poisson Learning: Graph Based Semi-Supervised
1160        Learning at Very Low Label Rates.](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v119/calder20a.html), 
1161        Proceedings of the 37th International Conference on Machine Learning, PMLR 119:1306-1316, 2020.
1162
1163        [3] Z. Shi, S. Osher, and W. Zhu. [Weighted nonlocal laplacian on interpolation from sparse data.](https://idp.springer.com/authorize/casa?redirect_uri=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10915-017-0421-z&casa_token=33Z7gqJy3mMAAAAA:iMO0pGmpn_qf5PioVIGocSRq_p4CDm-KNOQhgIC1uvqG9pWlZ6t7I-IZtSJfocFDEHCdMpK8j7Fx1XbzDQ)
1164        Journal of Scientific Computing 73.2 (2017): 1164-1177.
1165
1166        [4] J. Calder, D. Slepčev. [Properly-weighted graph Laplacian for semi-supervised learning.](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00245-019-09637-3) Applied mathematics & optimization (2019): 1-49.
1167        """
1168        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1169
1170        self.reweighting = reweighting
1171        self.normalization = normalization
1172        self.mean_shift = mean_shift
1173        self.tol = tol
1174        self.order = order
1175        self.X = X
1176
1177        #Set up tau
1178        if type(tau) in [float,int]:
1179            self.tau = np.ones(self.graph.num_nodes)*tau
1180        elif type(tau) is np.ndarray:
1181            self.tau = tau
1182
1183        #Setup accuracy filename
1184        fname = '_laplace' 
1185        self.name = 'Laplace Learning'
1186        if self.reweighting != 'none':
1187            fname += '_' + self.reweighting
1188            self.name += ': ' + self.reweighting + ' reweighted'
1189        if self.normalization != 'combinatorial':
1190            fname += '_' + self.normalization
1191            self.name += ' ' + self.normalization
1192        if self.mean_shift:
1193            fname += '_meanshift'
1194            self.name += ' with meanshift'
1195        if self.order > 1:
1196            self.name += ' order %d'%int(self.order)
1197        if np.max(self.tau) > 0:
1198            fname += '_tau_%.3f'%np.max(self.tau)
1199            self.name += ' tau=%.3f'%np.max(self.tau)
1200
1201        self.accuracy_filename = fname
1202
1203
1204    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1205
1206        #Reweighting
1207        if self.reweighting == 'none':
1208            G = self.graph
1209        else:
1210            W = self.graph.reweight(train_ind, method=self.reweighting, normalization=self.normalization, X=self.X)
1211            #W = self.graph.reweight(train_ind, method=self.reweighting, X=self.X)
1212            G = graph.graph(W)
1213
1214        #Get some attributes
1215        n = G.num_nodes
1216        unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
1217        k = len(unique_labels)
1218        
1219        #tau + Graph Laplacian and one-hot labels
1220        L = sparse.spdiags(self.tau, 0, G.num_nodes, G.num_nodes) + G.laplacian(normalization=self.normalization)
1221        if self.order > 1:
1222            Lpow = L*L
1223            if self.order > 2:
1224                for i in range(2,self.order):
1225                    Lpow = L*Lpow
1226            L = Lpow
1227        F = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1228
1229        #Locations of unlabeled points
1230        idx = np.full((n,), True, dtype=bool)
1231        idx[train_ind] = False
1232
1233        #Right hand side
1234        b = -L[:,train_ind]*F
1235        b = b[idx,:]
1236
1237        #Left hand side matrix
1238        A = L[idx,:]
1239        A = A[:,idx]
1240
1241        #Preconditioner
1242        m = A.shape[0]
1243        M = A.diagonal()
1244        M = sparse.spdiags(1/np.sqrt(M+1e-10),0,m,m).tocsr()
1245       
1246        #Conjugate gradient solver
1247        v = utils.conjgrad(M*A*M, M*b, tol=self.tol)
1248        v = M*v
1249
1250        #Add labels back into array
1251        u = np.zeros((n,k))
1252        u[idx,:] = v
1253        u[train_ind,:] = F
1254
1255        #Mean shift
1256        if self.mean_shift:
1257            u -= np.mean(u,axis=0)
1258
1259        return u
1260
1261class dynamic_label_propagation(ssl):
1262    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, alpha=0.05, lam=0.1, T=2):
1263        """Dynamic Label Propagation
1264        ===================
1265
1266        Semi-supervised learning via dynamic label propagation [1].
1267
1268        Parameters
1269        ----------
1270        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1271            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1272        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1273            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1274            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1275            nodes in each class.
1276        alpha : float (optional), default=0.05
1277            Value of parameter \\(\\alpha\\).
1278        lam : float (optional), default=0.1
1279            Value of parameter \\(\\lambda\\).
1280        T : int (optional), default=2
1281            Number of iterations.
1282
1283        References
1284        ---------
1285        [1] B. Wang, Z. Tu, and J.K. Tsotsos. [Dynamic label propagation for semi-supervised multi-class multi-label classification.](https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_iccv_2013/html/Wang_Dynamic_Label_Propagation_2013_ICCV_paper.html) Proceedings of the IEEE international conference on computer vision. 2013.
1286        """
1287        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1288
1289        self.alpha = alpha
1290        self.lam = lam
1291        self.T = T
1292
1293        self.accuracy_filename = '_dynamic_label_propagation'
1294        self.name = 'Dynamic Label Propagation'
1295 
1296
1297    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1298
1299        #Short forms
1300        alpha = self.alpha
1301        lam = self.lam
1302        T = self.T
1303        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1304        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1305
1306        #Zero out diagonal 
1307        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
1308        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
1309        G = graph.graph(W)
1310        
1311        #Labels to vector and correct position
1312        K = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1313        u = np.zeros((n,k))
1314        u[train_ind,:] = K 
1315      
1316        if n > 5000:
1317            print("Cannot use Dynamic Label Propagation on large datasets.")
1318        else:
1319            #Setup matrices
1320            Id = sparse.identity(n) 
1321            D = G.degree_matrix(p=-1)
1322            P = D*W
1323            P = np.array(P.todense())
1324            Pt = np.copy(P)
1325
1326            for i in range(T):
1327                v = P@u
1328                u = Pt@u
1329                u[train_ind,:] = K
1330                Pt = P@Pt@np.transpose(P) + alpha*v@np.transpose(v) + lam*Id
1331
1332                #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1333                if all_labels is not None:
1334                    self.prob = np.array(u)
1335                    labels = self.predict()
1336                    acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1337                    print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1338
1339            u = np.array(u)
1340
1341        return u
1342

1344class centered_kernel(ssl):
1345    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, tol=1e-10, power_it=100, alpha=1.05):
1346        """Centered Kernel Method
1347        ===================
1348
1349        Semi-supervised learning via the centered kernel method of [1].
1350
1351        Parameters
1352        ----------
1353        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1354            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1355        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1356            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1357            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1358            nodes in each class.
1359        tol : float (optional), default=1e-10
1360            Tolerance to solve equation.
1361        power_it : int (optional), default=100
1362            Number of power iterations to find largest eigenvalue.
1363        alpha : float (optional), default = 1.05
1364            Value of \\(\\alpha\\) as a fraction of largest eigenvalue.
1365
1366        References
1367        ---------
1368        [1] X. Mai and R. Couillet. [Random matrix-inspired improved semi-supervised learning on graphs.](https://romaincouillet.hebfree.org/docs/conf/SSL_ICML18.pdf) International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.
1369        """
1370        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1371
1372        self.tol = tol
1373        self.power_it = power_it
1374        self.alpha = alpha
1375
1376        self.accuracy_filename = '_centered_kernel'
1377        self.name = 'Centered Kernel'
1378        
1379    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1380
1381        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1382        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1383
1384        #Zero diagonal
1385        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
1386        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
1387
1388        #Indicator of train_ind
1389        K = np.zeros((n,k))
1390        K[train_ind] = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1391        
1392        #Center labels
1393        K[train_ind,:] -= np.sum(K,axis=0)/len(train_ind)
1394
1395        #Initialization
1396        u = np.copy(K)
1397        v = np.ones((n,1))
1398        vt = np.ones((1,n))
1399
1400        e = np.random.rand(n,1)
1401        for i in range(self.power_it):
1402            y = W*(e -  (1/n)*v@(vt@e))
1403            w = y - (1/n)*v@(vt@y) #=Ae
1404            l = abs(np.transpose(e)@w/(np.transpose(e)@e))
1405            e = w/np.linalg.norm(w)
1406
1407        #Number of iterations
1408        alpha = self.alpha * l
1409        err = 1
1410        while err > self.tol:
1411            y = W*(u -  (1/n)*v@(vt@u))
1412            w = (1/alpha)*(y - (1/n)*v@(vt@y)) - u #Laplacian
1413            w[train_ind,:] = 0
1414            err = np.max(np.absolute(w))
1415            u = u + w
1416
1417            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1418            if all_labels is not None:
1419                self.prob = u
1420                labels = self.predict()
1421                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1422                print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1423            
1424        return u
1425
1426
1427class sparse_label_propagation(ssl):
1428    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, T=100):
1429        """Sparse Label Propagation
1430        ===================
1431
1432        Semi-supervised learning via the sparse label propagation method of [1].
1433
1434        Parameters
1435        ----------
1436        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1437            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1438        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1439            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1440            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1441            nodes in each class.
1442        T : int (optional), default=100
1443            Number of iterations
1444
1445        References
1446        ---------
1447        [1] A. Jung, A.O. Hero III, A. Mara, and S. Jahromi. [Semi-supervised learning via sparse label propagation.](https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.01414) arXiv:1612.01414, 2016.
1448        """
1449        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1450
1451        self.T = T
1452        self.accuracy_filename = '_sparse_label_propagation'
1453        self.name = 'Sparse LP'
1454        
1455    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1456
1457        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1458        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1459
1460        #Sparse matrix with ones in all entries
1461        B = self.graph.adjacency()
1462
1463        #Construct matrix 1/2W and 1/deg
1464        lam = 2*self.graph.weight_matrix - (1-1e-10)*B
1465        lam = -lam.log1p()
1466        lam = lam.expm1() + B
1467        Id = sparse.identity(n) 
1468        gamma = self.graph.degree_matrix(p=-1)
1469
1470        #Random initial labeling
1471        u = np.zeros((k,n))
1472
1473        #Indicator of train_ind
1474        one_hot_labels = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels).T
1475
1476        #Initialization
1477        Y = list()
1478        for j in range(k):
1479            Gu = self.graph.gradient(u[j,:], weighted=True)
1480            Y.append(Gu)
1481
1482        #Main loop for sparse label propagation
1483        for i in range(self.T):
1484
1485            u_prev = np.copy(u)
1486            #Compute div
1487            for j in range(k):
1488                div = 2*self.graph.divergence(Y[j])
1489                u[j,:] = u_prev[j,:] - gamma*div
1490                u[j,train_ind] = one_hot_labels[j,:]  #Set labels
1491                u_tilde = 2*u[j,:] - u_prev[j,:]
1492
1493                Gu = -self.graph.gradient(u_tilde, weighted=True)
1494                Y[j] = Y[j] + Gu.multiply(lam)
1495                ind1 = B.multiply(abs(Y[j])>1)
1496                ind2 = B - ind1
1497                Y[j] = ind1.multiply(Y[j].sign()) + ind2.multiply(Y[j])
1498
1499            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1500            if all_labels is not None:
1501                self.prob = u.T
1502                labels = self.predict()
1503                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1504                print('%d,Accuracy = %.2f'%(i,acc))
1505 
1506        return u.T
1507
1508
1509class graph_nearest_neighbor(ssl):
1510    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, D=None, alpha=1):
1511        """Graph nearest neighbor classifier
1512        ===================
1513
1514        Semi-supervised learning by graph (geodesic) nearest neighbor classifier. The 
1515        graph geodesic distance is defined by
1516        \\[ d_{ij} = \\min_p \\sum_{k=1}^M w_{p_k,p_{k+1}},\\]
1517        where the minimum is over paths \\(p\\) connecting nodes \\(i\\) and \\(j\\). The label
1518        returned for each testing point is the label of the closest labeled point.
1519
1520        Parameters
1521        ----------
1522        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1523            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1524        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1525            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1526            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1527            nodes in each class.
1528        D : numpy array or scipy sparse matrix (optional)
1529            (n,n) Distance matrix, giving distances between neighbors. If provided,
1530            this is used to construct a knn density estimator for reweighting the eikonal equation.
1531        alpha : float (optional), default=1
1532            Reweighting exponent.
1533        """
1534        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1535
1536
1537        self.alpha = alpha
1538
1539        if class_priors is not None:
1540            self.onevsrest = True
1541            self.similarity = False
1542
1543        #Cannot reweight if distance matrix not provided
1544        if D is None:
1545            self.f = 1
1546        else:
1547            d = D.max(axis=1).toarray().flatten() #distance to furtherest neighbor
1548            self.f = (d/np.max(d))**alpha
1549
1550        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1551        self.accuracy_filename = '_graph_nearest_neighbor_alpha%.2f'%(self.alpha) 
1552        self.name = 'Graph NN (alpha=%.2f)'%(self.alpha)
1553
1554    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1555
1556        if self.onevsrest:
1557            u = self.graph.dijkstra(train_ind[train_labels], bdy_val=0, f=self.f)
1558        else: 
1559            _,l = self.graph.dijkstra(train_ind, bdy_val=np.zeros_like(train_ind), f=self.f, return_cp=True)
1560            u = np.zeros(l.shape)
1561            u[train_ind] = train_labels
1562            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(u[l])
1563
1564        return u
1565
1566class amle(ssl):
1567    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, tol=1e-3, max_num_it=1e5, weighted=False, prog=False):
1568        """AMLE learning
1569        ===================
1570
1571        Semi-supervised learning by the Absolutely Minimal Lipschitz Extension (AMLE). This is the same as
1572        p-Laplace with \\(p=\\infty\\), except that AMLE has an option `weighted=False` that significantly 
1573        accelerates the solver.
1574
1575        Parameters
1576        ----------
1577        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1578            (n,n) Weight matrix representing the graph.
1579        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1580            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1581            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1582            nodes in each class.
1583        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
1584            Tolerance with which to solve the equation.
1585        max_num_it : int (optional), default=1e5
1586            Maximum number of iterations
1587        weighted : bool (optional), default=False
1588            When False, the graph is converted to a 0/1 adjacency matrix, which affords a much faster solver.
1589        prog : bool (optional), default=False
1590            Whether to print progress information.
1591        """
1592        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1593
1594        self.tol = tol
1595        self.max_num_it = max_num_it
1596        self.weighted = weighted
1597        self.prog = prog
1598        self.onevsrest = True
1599
1600        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1601        self.accuracy_filename = '_amle'
1602        if not self.weighted:
1603            self.accuracy_filename += '_unweighted'
1604        self.name = 'AMLE'
1605
1606
1607    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1608
1609        u = self.graph.amle(train_ind, train_labels, tol=self.tol, max_num_it=self.max_num_it, 
1610                                                     weighted=self.weighted, prog=self.prog)
1611        return u
1612
1613class peikonal(ssl):
1614    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, D=None, p=1, alpha=1, max_num_it=1e5, tol=1e-3, num_bisection_it=30, eps_ball_graph=False):
1615        """Graph p-eikonal classifier
1616        ===================
1617
1618        Semi-supervised learning by via the solution of the graph `graph.peikonal` equation.
1619
1620        Parameters
1621        ----------
1622        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1623            (n,n) Weight matrix representing the graph.
1624        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1625            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1626            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1627            nodes in each class.
1628        D : numpy array or scipy sparse matrix (optional)
1629            (n,n) Distance matrix, giving distances between neighbors. If provided,
1630            this is used to construct a knn density estimator for reweighting the p-eikonal equation.
1631        p : float (optional), default=1
1632            Value of exponent p in the p-eikonal equation
1633        alpha : float (optional), default=1
1634            Reweighting exponent.
1635        max_num_it : int (optional), default=1e5
1636            Maximum number of iterations.
1637        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
1638            Tolerance with which to solve the equation.
1639        num_bisection_it : int (optional), default=30
1640            Number of bisection iterations for solver.
1641        eps_ball_graph : bool (optional), default=False
1642            Whether the graph is an epsilon-ball graph or not. If it is, then the density reweighting
1643            will be done with the degree vector, which is a kernel density estimator in this case
1644        """
1645        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1646
1647        self.p = p
1648        self.alpha = alpha
1649        self.max_num_it = max_num_it
1650        self.tol = tol
1651        self.num_bisection_it = num_bisection_it
1652        self.onevsrest = True
1653        self.similarity = False
1654
1655        #Cannot reweight if distance matrix not provided
1656        if D is None:
1657            if eps_ball_graph:
1658                d = self.graph.degree_vector()
1659                self.f = (d/np.max(d))**(-alpha)
1660            else:
1661                self.f = 1
1662        else:
1663            d = D.max(axis=1).toarray().flatten() #distance to furtherest neighbor
1664            self.f = (d/np.max(d))**alpha
1665
1666        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1667        self.accuracy_filename = '_peikonal_p%.2f_alpha%.2f'%(self.p,self.alpha) 
1668        self.name = 'p-eikonal (p=%.2f, alpha=%.2f)'%(self.p,self.alpha)
1669
1670
1671    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1672
1673        u = self.graph.peikonal(train_ind[train_labels], bdy_val=0, f=self.f, p=self.p, max_num_it=self.max_num_it, 
1674                                                tol=self.tol, num_bisection_it=self.num_bisection_it, prog=False)
1675        return u
1676
1677
1678class plaplace(ssl):
1679    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, p=10, max_num_it=1e6, tol=1e-1, fast=True):
1680        """Graph p-laplace classifier
1681        ===================
1682
1683        Semi-supervised learning by via the solution of the game-theoretic p-Laplace equation [1].
1684
1685        Parameters
1686        ----------
1687        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1688            (n,n) Weight matrix representing the graph.
1689        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1690            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1691            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1692            nodes in each class.
1693        p : float (optional), default=10
1694            Value of p in the p-Laplace equation (\\( 2 \\leq p \\leq \\infty\\).
1695        max_num_it : int (optional), default=1e5
1696            Maximum number of iterations
1697        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
1698            Tolerance with which to solve the equation.
1699        fast : bool (optional), default=True
1700            Whether to use constant \\(w_{ij}=1\\) weights for the infinity-Laplacian
1701            which allows a faster algorithm to be used.
1702
1703        References
1704        ----------
1705        [1] M. Flores Rios, J. Calder, and G. Lerman. [Algorithms for \\( \\ell_p\\)-based semi-supervised learning on graphs.](https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.05031) arXiv:1901.05031, 2019.
1706        """
1707        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1708
1709        self.p = p
1710        self.max_num_it = max_num_it
1711        self.tol = tol
1712        self.onevsrest = True
1713        self.fast = fast
1714
1715        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1716        self.accuracy_filename = '_plaplace_p%.2f'%self.p 
1717        self.name = 'p-Laplace (p=%.2f)'%self.p
1718
1719
1720    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1721        u = self.graph.plaplace(train_ind, train_labels, self.p, max_num_it=self.max_num_it, tol=self.tol,fast=self.fast)
1722        return u
1723

1726class randomwalk(ssl):
1727    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, alpha=0.95):
1728        """Lazy random walk classification
1729        ===================
1730
1731        Add description.
1732
1733        The original method was introduced in [1], and can be interpreted as a lazy random walk. 
1734
1735        Parameters
1736        ----------
1737        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1738            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1739        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1740            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1741            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1742            nodes in each class.
1743        alpha : float (optional), default=0.95
1744            Parameter in model.
1745
1746        References
1747        ---------
1748        [1] D. Zhou and B. Schölkopf. [Learning from labeled and unlabeled data using random walks.](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-540-28649-3_29) Joint Pattern Recognition Symposium. 
1749        Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg, 2004.
1750        """
1751        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1752
1753        self.alpha = alpha
1754
1755        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1756        self.accuracy_filename = '_randomwalk' 
1757        self.name = 'Lazy Random Walks'
1758
1759
1760    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1761        
1762        alpha = self.alpha
1763
1764        #Zero diagonals
1765        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1766        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
1767        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
1768        G = graph.graph(W)
1769
1770        #Construct Laplacian matrix
1771        L = (1-alpha)*sparse.identity(n) + alpha*G.laplacian(normalization='normalized')
1772
1773        #Preconditioner
1774        m = L.shape[0]
1775        M = L.diagonal()
1776        M = sparse.spdiags(1/np.sqrt(M+1e-10),0,m,m).tocsr()
1777       
1778        #Right hand side
1779        onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1780        Y = np.zeros((n, onehot.shape[1]))
1781        Y[train_ind,:] = onehot
1782
1783        #Conjugate gradient solver
1784        u = utils.conjgrad(M*L*M, M*Y, tol=1e-6)
1785        u = M*u
1786
1787        return u
1788
1789def ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, true_labels, train_ind):   
1790    """SSL Accuacy
1791    ======
1792
1793    Accuracy for semi-supervised graph learning, taking care to remove training set.
1794    NOTE: Any true labels with negative values will be removed from 
1795    accuracy computation.
1796
1797    Parameters
1798    ----------
1799    pred_labels : numpy array, int
1800        Predicted labels
1801    true_labels : numpy array, int
1802        True labels
1803    train_ind : numpy array, int 
1804        Indices of training points, which will be removed from the accuracy computation.
1805
1806    Returns
1807    -------
1808    accuracy : float
1809        Accuracy as a number in [0,100].
1810    """
1811
1812        #Remove labeled data
1813    mask = np.ones(len(pred_labels),dtype=bool)
1814    if type(train_ind) != np.ndarray:
1815        print("Warning: ssl_accuracy has been updated and now requires the user to provide the indices of the labeled points, and not just the number of labels. Accuracy computation will be incorrect unless you update your code accordingly. See https://jwcalder.github.io/GraphLearning/ssl.html#two-moons-example")
1816    else:
1817        mask[train_ind]=False
1818
1819    pred_labels = pred_labels[mask]
1820    true_labels = true_labels[mask]
1821
1822    #Remove unlabeled nodes
1823    I = true_labels >=0
1824    pred_labels = pred_labels[I]
1825    true_labels = true_labels[I]
1826
1827    #Compute accuracy
1828    return 100*np.mean(pred_labels==true_labels)
1829
