1831def accuracy_plot(model_list, tag='', testerror=False, savefile=None, title=None, errorbars=False, 
1832                  loglog=False, ylim=None, fontsize=16, legend_fontsize=16, label_fontsize=16):
1833    """Accuracy Plot
1834    ======
1835
1836    Creates a plot of accuracy scores for experiments run with `ssl_trials`.
1837
1838    Parameters
1839    ----------
1840    model_list : list of ssl objects
1841        Models to include in table.
1842    tag : str (optional), default=''
1843        An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
1844    testerror : bool (optional), default=False
1845        Show test error (instead of accuracy) in the table.
1846    savefile : str (optional), default=None
1847        If a savefile name is provided, then the plot is saved instead of displayed to the screen
1848    title : str (optional), default=None
1849        If title is provided, then it will be added to the plot.
1850    errorbars : bool (optional), default=False
1851        Whether to add error bars to plot.
1852    loglog : bool (optional), default=False
1853        Make the plot on a loglog scale.
1854    ylim : tuple (optional), default=None
1855        If provided, then y-limits are set with `plt.ylim(ylim)`
1856    fontsize : int (optional), default=16
1857        Font size text, other than legend and labels
1858    legend_fontsize : int (optional), default=16
1859        Font size for legend.
1860    label_fontsize : int (optional), default=16
1861        Font size for x and y labels.
1862    """
1863
1864    fig = plt.figure()
1865    if errorbars:
1866        matplotlib.rcParams.update({'errorbar.capsize': 5})
1867    matplotlib.rcParams.update({'font.size': fontsize})
1868    styles = ['^b-','or-','dg-','sk-','pm-','xc-','*y-']
1869    i = -1
1870    for model in model_list:
1871        i = (i+1)%7
1872        num_train,acc_mean,acc_stddev,num_trials = model.trials_statistics(tag=tag)
1873        if testerror:
1874            acc_mean = 100-acc_mean
1875
1876        if errorbars:
1877            plt.errorbar(num_train, acc_mean[:,0], fmt=styles[i], yerr=acc_stddev[:,0], label=model.name)
1878        else:
1879            if loglog:
1880                plt.loglog(num_train, acc_mean[:,0], styles[i], label=model.name)
1881            else:
1882                plt.plot(num_train, acc_mean[:,0], styles[i], label=model.name) #3rd argumnet=styles[i]
1883
1884        #If class priors were run as well
1885        if acc_mean.shape[1] > 1:
1886            i = (i+1)%7
1887            if errorbars:
1888                plt.errorbar(num_train, acc_mean[:,1], fmt=styles[i], yerr=acc_stddev[:,1], label=model.name+'+CP')
1889            else:
1890                if loglog:
1891                    plt.loglog(num_train, acc_mean[:,1], styles[i], label=model.name+'+CP')
1892                else:
1893                    plt.plot(num_train, acc_mean[:,1], styles[i], label=model.name+'+CP') #3rd argumnet=styles[i]
1894
1895     
1896    plt.xlabel('Number of labels',fontsize=label_fontsize)
1897    if testerror:
1898        plt.ylabel('Test error (%)',fontsize=label_fontsize)
1899        plt.legend(loc='upper right',fontsize=legend_fontsize)
1900    else:
1901        plt.ylabel('Accuracy (%)',fontsize=label_fontsize)
1902        plt.legend(loc='lower right',fontsize=legend_fontsize)
1903    if title is not None:
1904        plt.title(title)
1905
1906    plt.tight_layout()
1907    plt.grid(True)
1908
1909    if ylim is not None:
1910        plt.ylim(ylim)
1911
1912    #ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(MaxNLocator(integer=True))
1913
1914    if savefile is not None:
1915        plt.savefig(savefile)
1916    else:
1917        plt.show()

1919def accuracy_table(model_list, tag='', testerror=False, savefile='table.tex', title='', 
1920                               append=False, fontsize='small', small_caps=True, two_column=True):
1921    """Accuracy table
1922    ======
1923
1924    Creates a table of accuracy scores for experiments run with `ssl_trials` to be
1925    included in a LaTeX document.
1926
1927    Parameters
1928    ----------
1929    model_list : list of ssl objects
1930        Models to include in table.
1931    tag : str (optional), default=''
1932        An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
1933    testerror : bool (optional), default=False
1934        Show test error (instead of accuracy) in the table.
1935    savefile : str (optional), default='table.tex'
1936        Filename to save tex code for table.
1937    title : str (optional), default=''
1938        Title for table.
1939    append : bool (optional), default=False
1940        Whether to create a new tex file or append table to existing file.
1941    fontsize : str (optional), default='small'
1942        LaTeX font size.
1943    small_caps : bool (optional), default=True
1944        Whether to use small caps in LaTeX for table.
1945    two_column : bool (optional), default=True
1946        Whether the table will be in a two-column LaTeX document.
1947    """
1948
1949
1950    num_train,acc_mean,acc_stddev,num_trials = model_list[0].trials_statistics(tag=tag)
1951    m = len(num_train)
1952
1953    #Determine best algorithm at each label rate
1954    best = [None]*m
1955    class_priors_best = [False]*m
1956    best_score = [0]*m
1957    for i, model in enumerate(model_list):
1958        num_train,acc_mean,acc_stddev,num_trials = model.trials_statistics(tag=tag)
1959        for j in range(m):
1960            if acc_mean[j,0] > best_score[j]:
1961                best_score[j] = acc_mean[j,0]
1962                best[j] = i
1963
1964        #Check if class priors accuracy was included as well
1965        if acc_mean.shape[1] > 1:
1966            for j in range(m):
1967                if acc_mean[j,1] > best_score[j]:
1968                    best_score[j] = acc_mean[j,1]
1969                    class_priors_best[j] = True
1970                    best[j] = i
1971
1972    
1973    if append:
1974        f = open(savefile,"r")
1975        lines = f.readlines()
1976        f.close()
1977        f = open(savefile,"w")
1978        f.writelines([item for item in lines[:-1]])
1979    else:
1980        f = open(savefile,"w")
1981        f.write("\\documentclass{article}\n")
1982        f.write("\\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}\n")
1983        f.write("\\usepackage{booktabs}\n")
1984        f.write("\\usepackage[margin=1in]{geometry}\n")
1985        f.write("\\begin{document}\n")
1986
1987    f.write("\n\n\n")
1988    if two_column:
1989        f.write("\\begin{table*}[t!]\n")
1990    else:
1991        f.write("\\begin{table}[t!]\n")
1992    f.write("\\vspace{-3mm}\n")
1993    f.write("\\caption{"+title+": Average (standard deviation) classification accuracy over %d trials.}\n"%num_trials)
1994    f.write("\\vspace{-3mm}\n")
1995    f.write("\\label{tab:"+title+"}\n")
1996    f.write("\\vskip 0.15in\n")
1997    f.write("\\begin{center}\n")
1998    f.write("\\begin{"+fontsize+"}\n")
1999    if small_caps:
2000        f.write("\\begin{sc}\n")
2001    f.write("\\begin{tabular}{l")
2002    for i in range(m):
2003        f.write("l")
2004    f.write("}\n")
2005    f.write("\\toprule\n")
2006    f.write("\\# Labels")
2007    for i in range(m):
2008        f.write("&\\textbf{%d}"%int(num_train[i]))
2009    f.write("\\\\\n")
2010    f.write("\\midrule\n")
2011    i = 0
2012
2013    for i, model in enumerate(model_list):
2014        num_train,acc_mean,acc_stddev,num_trials = model.trials_statistics(tag=tag)
2015
2016        f.write(model.name.ljust(15))
2017        for j in range(m):
2018            if best[j] == i and not class_priors_best[j]: 
2019                f.write("&{\\bf %.1f"%acc_mean[j,0]+" (%.1f)}"%acc_stddev[j,0])
2020            else:
2021                f.write("&%.1f"%acc_mean[j,0]+" (%.1f)      "%acc_stddev[j,0])
2022        f.write("\\\\\n")
2023        
2024        #Check if class priors accuracy was included as well
2025        if acc_mean.shape[1] > 1:
2026            f.write((model.name+'+CP').ljust(15))
2027            for j in range(m):
2028                if best[j] == i and class_priors_best[j]: 
2029                    f.write("&{\\bf %.1f"%acc_mean[j,1]+" (%.1f)}"%acc_stddev[j,1])
2030                else:
2031                    f.write("&%.1f"%acc_mean[j,1]+" (%.1f)      "%acc_stddev[j,1])
2032            f.write("\\\\\n")
2033
2034    f.write("\\bottomrule\n")
2035    f.write("\\end{tabular}\n")
2036    if small_caps:
2037        f.write("\\end{sc}\n")
2038    f.write("\\end{"+fontsize+"}\n")
2039    f.write("\\end{center}\n")
2040    f.write("\\vskip -0.1in\n")
2041    if two_column:
2042        f.write("\\end{table*}")
2043    else:
2044        f.write("\\end{table}")
2045    f.write("\n\n\n")
2046    f.write("\\end{document}\n")
2047    f.close()

class ssl: 
132class ssl:
133    __metaclass__ = ABCMeta
134
135    def __init__(self, W, class_priors):
136        if W is None:
137            self.graph = None
138        else:
139            self.set_graph(W)
140        self.prob = None
141        self.fitted = False
142        self.name = ''
143        self.accuracy_filename = ''
144        self.requires_eig = False
145        self.onevsrest = False
146        self.similarity = True
147        self.class_priors = class_priors
148        if self.class_priors is not None:
149            self.class_priors = self.class_priors / np.sum(self.class_priors)
150        self.weights = 1
151        self.class_priors_error = 1
152
153    def set_graph(self, W):
154        """Set Graph
155        ===================
156
157        Sets the graph object for semi-supervised learning.
158
159        Implements 3 different solvers, spectral, gradient_descent, and conjugate_gradient. 
160        GPU acceleration is available for gradient descent. See [1] for details.
161
162        Parameters
163        ----------
164        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
165            Weight matrix representing the graph.
166        """
167
168        if type(W) == graph.graph:
169            self.graph = W
170        else:
171            self.graph = graph.graph(W)
172
173    def volume_label_projection(self):
174        """Volume label projection
175        ======
176    
177        Projects class probabilities to labels while enforcing a constraint on 
178        class priors (i.e., class volumes). Does not return anything, just modifies `self.weights`.
179        
180        Returns
181        -------
182        labels : numpy array (int)
183            Predicted labels after volume correction.
184        """
185
186        n = self.graph.num_nodes
187        k = self.prob.shape[1]
188        if type(self.weights) == int:
189            self.weights = np.ones((k,))
190
191        #Time step
192        dt = 0.1
193        if self.similarity:
194            dt *= -1
195
196        #np.set_printoptions(formatter={'float': lambda x: "{0:0.3f}".format(x)})
197        i = 0
198        err = 1
199        while i < 1e4 and err > 1e-3:
200            i += 1
201            class_size = np.mean(utils.labels_to_onehot(self.predict()),axis=0)
202            #print(class_size-self.class_priors)
203            grad = class_size - self.class_priors
204            err = np.max(np.absolute(grad))
205            self.weights += dt*grad
206            self.weights = self.weights/self.weights[0]
207
208        self.class_priors_error = err
209
210        return self.predict()
211
212    def get_accuracy_filename(self):
213        """Get accuracy filename
214        ========
215
216        Returns name of the file that will store the accuracy results for `ssl_trials.py`.
217
218        Returns
219        -------
220        fname : str
221            Accuracy filename.
222        """
223
224        fname = self.accuracy_filename
225        if self.class_priors is not None:
226            fname += '_classpriors'
227        fname += '_accuracy.csv'
228        return fname
229
230
231    def predict(self, ignore_class_priors=False):
232        """Predict
233        ========
234
235        Makes label predictions based on the probabilities computed by `fit()`.
236        Will use a volume label projection if `class_priors` were given, to ensure 
237        the number of nodes predicted in each class is correct.
238        
239        Parameters
240        ----------
241        ignore_class_priors : bool (optional), default=False
242            Used to disable the volume constrained label decision, when `class_priors` has been provided. 
243
244        Returns
245        -------
246        pred_labels : (int) numpy array
247            Predicted labels as integers for all datapoints in the graph.
248        """
249
250        if self.fitted == False:
251            sys.exit('Model has not been fitted yet.')
252
253        if ignore_class_priors:
254            w = 1
255        else:
256            w = self.weights
257
258        scores = self.prob - np.min(self.prob)
259        scores = scores/np.max(scores)
260
261        #Check if scores are similarity or distance
262        if self.similarity:
263            pred_labels = np.argmax(scores*w,axis=1)
264        else: #Then distances
265            pred_labels = np.argmin(scores*w,axis=1)
266
267        return pred_labels 
268
269    def fit_predict(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
270        """Fit and predict
271        ======
272
273        Calls fit() and predict() sequentially.
274
275        Parameters
276        ----------
277        train_ind : numpy array, int
278            Indicies of training points.
279        train_labels : numpy array, int
280            Training labels as integers \\(0,1,\\dots,k-1\\) for \\(k\\) classes.
281        all_labels : numpy array, int (optional)
282            True labels for all datapoints.
283
284        Returns
285        -------
286        pred_labels : (int) numpy array
287            Predicted labels as integers for all datapoints in the graph.
288        """
289
290        self.fit(train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=all_labels)
291        return self.predict()
292
293    def ssl_trials(self, trainsets, labels, num_cores=1, tag='', save_results=True, overwrite=False, num_trials=-1):
294        """Semi-supervised learning trials
295        ===================
296
297        Runs a semi-supervised learning algorithm on a list of training sets,
298        recording the label rates and saves the results to a csv file in the
299        local folder results/. The filename is controlled by the member function
300        model.get_accuracy_filename(). The trial will abort if the accuracy result
301        file already exists, unless `overwrite=True`.
302
303        Parameters
304        ----------
305        trainsets : list of numpy arrays
306            Collection of training sets to run semi-supervised learning on. This is the output
307            of `graphlearning.trainsets.generate` or `graphlearning.trainsets.load`.
308        labels : numpy array (int)
309            Integer array of labels for entire dataset.
310        num_cores : int
311            Number of cores to use for parallel processing over trials
312        tag : str (optional), default=''
313            An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
314        save_results : bool (optional), default=True
315            Whether to save results to csv file or just print to the screen.
316        overwrite : bool (optional), default = False
317            Whether to overwrite existing results file, if found. If `overwrite=False`, 
318            `save_results=True`, and the results file is found, the trial is aborted.
319        num_trials: int (optional), defualt = -1
320            Number of trials. Any negative number runs all trials.
321        """
322
323        if num_trials > 0:
324            trainsets = trainsets[:num_trials]
325
326        #Print name
327        print('\nModel: '+self.name)
328
329        if save_results:
330            if not os.path.exists(results_dir):
331                os.makedirs(results_dir)
332
333            outfile = os.path.join(results_dir, tag+self.get_accuracy_filename())
334            if (not overwrite) and os.path.exists(outfile):
335                print('Aborting: SSL trial already completed, and overwrite is False.')
336                return
337            f = open(outfile,"w")
338            #now = datetime.datetime.now()
339            #f.write("Date/Time, "+now.strftime("%Y-%m-%d_%H:%M")+"\n")
340            if self.class_priors is None:
341                f.write('Number of labels,Accuracy\n')
342            else:
343                f.write('Number of labels,Accuracy,Accuracy with class priors,Class priors error\n')
344            f.close()
345
346        if save_results:
347            print('Results File: '+outfile)
348
349        if self.class_priors is None:
350            print('\nNumber of labels,Accuracy')
351        else:
352            print('\nNumber of labels,Accuracy,Accuracy with class priors,Class priors error')
353
354        #Trial run to trigger eigensolvers, when needed
355        if self.requires_eig:
356            pred_labels = self.fit_predict(trainsets[0], labels[trainsets[0]])
357     
358        def one_trial(train_ind):
359
360            #Number of labels
361            num_train = len(train_ind)
362            train_labels = labels[train_ind]
363
364            #Run semi-supervised learning
365            pred_labels = self.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels)
366
367            #Compute accuracy
368            accuracy = ssl_accuracy(pred_labels,labels,train_ind)
369
370            #If class priors were provided, check accuracy without priors
371            if self.class_priors is not None:
372                pred_labels = self.predict(ignore_class_priors=True)
373                accuracy_without_priors = ssl_accuracy(pred_labels,labels,train_ind)
374            
375            #Print to terminal
376            if self.class_priors is None:
377                print("%d" % num_train + ",%.2f" % accuracy)
378            else:
379                print("%d,%.2f,%.2f,%.5f" % (num_train,accuracy_without_priors,accuracy,self.class_priors_error))
380
381            #Write to file
382            if save_results:
383                f = open(outfile,"a+")
384                if self.class_priors is None:
385                    f.write("%d" % num_train + ",%.2f\n" % accuracy)
386                else:
387                    f.write("%d,%.2f,%.2f,%.5f\n" % (num_train,accuracy_without_priors,accuracy,
388                                                                            self.class_priors_error))
389                f.close()
390
391        num_cores = min(multiprocessing.cpu_count(),num_cores)
392
393        if num_cores == 1:
394            for train_ind in trainsets:
395                one_trial(train_ind)
396        else:
397            Parallel(n_jobs=num_cores)(delayed(one_trial)(train_ind) for train_ind in trainsets)

399    def trials_statistics(self, tag=''):
400        """Trials statistics
401        ===================
402
403        Loads accuracy scores from each trial from csv files created by `ssl_trials`
404        and returns summary statistics (mean and standard deviation of accuracy).
405
406        Parameters
407        ----------
408        tag : str (optional), default=''
409            An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
410
411        Returns
412        -------
413        num_train : numpy array
414            Number of training examples in each label rate experiment.
415        acc_mean : numpy array
416            Mean accuracy over all trials in each experiment.
417        acc_stddev : numpy array
418            Standard deviation of accuracy over all trials in each experiment.
419        num_trials : int
420            Number of trials for each label rate.
421        """
422
423        accuracy_filename = os.path.join(results_dir, tag+self.get_accuracy_filename())
424        X = utils.csvread(accuracy_filename)
425        num_train = np.unique(X[:,0])
426
427        acc_mean = []
428        acc_stddev = []
429        for n in num_train:
430            Y = X[X[:,0]==n,1:]
431            acc_mean += [np.mean(Y,axis=0)]
432            acc_stddev += [np.std(Y,axis=0)]
433
434        num_trials = int(len(X[:,0])/len(num_train))
435        acc_mean = np.array(acc_mean)
436        acc_stddev = np.array(acc_stddev)
437        return num_train, acc_mean, acc_stddev, num_trials
438
439   
440    def fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
441        """Fit
442        ======
443
444        Solves graph-based learning problem, computing the probability 
445        that each node belongs to each class. If `all_labels` is provided, 
446        then the solver operates in verbose mode, printing out accuracy
447        at each iteration.
448
449        Parameters
450        ----------
451        train_ind : numpy array, int
452            Indicies of training points.
453        train_labels : numpy array, int
454            Training labels as integers \\(0,1,\\dots,k-1\\) for \\(k\\) classes.
455        all_labels : numpy array, int (optional)
456            True labels for all datapoints.
457
458        Returns
459        -------
460        u : (n,k) numpy array, float
461            Probabilities computed by graph-based learning for each node and each class.
462        """
463
464        if self.graph is None:
465            sys.exit('SSL object has no graph. Use graph.set_graph() to provide a graph for SSL.')
466
467        self.fitted = True
468
469        #If a one-vs-rest classifier
470        if self.onevsrest:
471            unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
472            num_labels = len(unique_labels)
473            self.prob = np.zeros((self.graph.num_nodes,num_labels))
474            for i,l in enumerate(unique_labels):
475                self.prob[:,i] = self._fit(train_ind, train_labels==l)
476        else:
477            self.prob = self._fit(train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=all_labels)
478
479        if self.class_priors is not None:
480            self.volume_label_projection()
481
482        return self.prob
483
484    @abstractmethod
485    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
486        """Internal Fit Function
487        ======
488
489        Internal fit function that any ssl object must override. If `self.onevsrest=True` then
490        `train_labels` are binary in the one-vs-rest framework, and `_fit` must return
491        a scalar numpy array. Otherwise the labels are integer and `_fit` must return an (n,k)
492        numpy array of probabilities, where `k` is the number of classes.
493
494        Parameters
495        ----------
496        train_ind : numpy array, int
497            Indicies of training points.
498        train_labels : numpy array, int
499            Training labels as integers \\(0,1,\\dots,k-1\\) for \\(k\\) classes, or binary
500            if `self.onevsrest=True`.
501        all_labels : numpy array, int (optional)
502            True labels for all datapoints.
503
504        Returns
505        -------
506        u : numpy array, float
507            (n,k) array of probabilities computed by graph-based learning for each node and each class, unless
508            `self.onevsrest=True`, in which case it is a length n numpy array of probablities for the current 
509            class.
510        """
511        raise NotImplementedError("Must override _fit")
ssl(W, class_priors) 
135    def __init__(self, W, class_priors):

141        self.fitted = False

143        self.accuracy_filename = ''
144        self.requires_eig = False
145        self.onevsrest = False
146        self.similarity = True
147        self.class_priors = class_priors
148        if self.class_priors is not None:

151        self.class_priors_error = 1

def volume_label_projection(self): 
173    def volume_label_projection(self):
174        """Volume label projection
175        ======
176    
177        Projects class probabilities to labels while enforcing a constraint on 
178        class priors (i.e., class volumes). Does not return anything, just modifies `self.weights`.
179        
180        Returns
181        -------
182        labels : numpy array (int)
183            Predicted labels after volume correction.
184        """
185
186        n = self.graph.num_nodes
187        k = self.prob.shape[1]
188        if type(self.weights) == int:
189            self.weights = np.ones((k,))
190
191        #Time step
192        dt = 0.1
193        if self.similarity:
194            dt *= -1
195
196        #np.set_printoptions(formatter={'float': lambda x: "{0:0.3f}".format(x)})
197        i = 0
198        err = 1
199        while i < 1e4 and err > 1e-3:
200            i += 1
201            class_size = np.mean(utils.labels_to_onehot(self.predict()),axis=0)
202            #print(class_size-self.class_priors)
203            grad = class_size - self.class_priors
204            err = np.max(np.absolute(grad))
205            self.weights += dt*grad
206            self.weights = self.weights/self.weights[0]
207
208        self.class_priors_error = err
209
210        return self.predict()

Volume label projection

Projects class probabilities to labels while enforcing a constraint on class priors (i.e., class volumes). Does not return anything, just modifies self.weights.

Returns
  • labels (numpy array (int)): Predicted labels after volume correction.

def predict(self, ignore_class_priors=False): 
231    def predict(self, ignore_class_priors=False):
232        """Predict
233        ========
234
235        Makes label predictions based on the probabilities computed by `fit()`.
236        Will use a volume label projection if `class_priors` were given, to ensure 
237        the number of nodes predicted in each class is correct.
238        
239        Parameters
240        ----------
241        ignore_class_priors : bool (optional), default=False
242            Used to disable the volume constrained label decision, when `class_priors` has been provided. 
243
244        Returns
245        -------
246        pred_labels : (int) numpy array
247            Predicted labels as integers for all datapoints in the graph.
248        """
249
250        if self.fitted == False:
251            sys.exit('Model has not been fitted yet.')
252
253        if ignore_class_priors:
254            w = 1
255        else:
256            w = self.weights
257
258        scores = self.prob - np.min(self.prob)
259        scores = scores/np.max(scores)
260
261        #Check if scores are similarity or distance
262        if self.similarity:
263            pred_labels = np.argmax(scores*w,axis=1)
264        else: #Then distances
265            pred_labels = np.argmin(scores*w,axis=1)
266
267        return pred_labels

Predict

Makes label predictions based on the probabilities computed by fit(). Will use a volume label projection if class_priors were given, to ensure the number of nodes predicted in each class is correct.

Parameters
  • ignore_class_priors (bool (optional), default=False): Used to disable the volume constrained label decision, when class_priors has been provided.
Returns
  • pred_labels ((int) numpy array): Predicted labels as integers for all datapoints in the graph.

class poisson(ssl): 
514class poisson(ssl):
515    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, solver='conjugate_gradient', p=1, use_cuda=False, min_iter=50, max_iter=1000, tol=1e-3, spectral_cutoff=10):
516        """Poisson Learning
517        ===================
518
519        Semi-supervised learning via the solution of the Poisson equation 
520        \\[L^p u = \\sum_{j=1}^m \\delta_j(y_j - \\overline{y})^T,\\]
521        where \\(L=D-W\\) is the combinatorial graph Laplacian, 
522        \\(y_j\\) are the label vectors, \\(\\overline{y} = \\frac{1}{m}\\sum_{i=1}^m y_j\\) 
523        is the average label vector, \\(m\\) is the number of training points, and 
524        \\(\\delta_j\\) are standard basis vectors. See the reference for more details.
525
526        Implements 3 different solvers, spectral, gradient_descent, and conjugate_gradient. 
527        GPU acceleration is available for gradient descent. See [1] for details.
528
529        Parameters
530        ----------
531        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
532            Weight matrix representing the graph.
533        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
534            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
535            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
536            nodes in each class.
537        solver : {'spectral', 'conjugate_gradient', 'gradient_descent'} (optional), default='conjugate_gradient'
538            Choice of solver for Poisson learning.
539        p : int (optional), default=1
540            Power for Laplacian, can be any positive real number. Solver will default to 'spectral' if p!=1.
541        use_cuda : bool (optional), default=False
542            Whether to use GPU acceleration for gradient descent solver.
543        min_iter : int (optional), default=50
544            Minimum number of iterations of gradient descent before checking stopping condition.
545        max_iter : int (optional), default=1000
546            Maximum number of iterations of gradient descent.
547        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
548            Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
549        spectral_cutoff : int (optional), default=10
550            Number of eigenvectors to use for spectral solver.
551
552        Examples
553        --------
554        Poisson learning works on directed (i.e., nonsymmetric) graphs with the gradient descent solver: [poisson_directed.py](https://github.com/jwcalder/GraphLearning/blob/master/examples/poisson_directed.py).
555        ```py
556        import numpy as np
557        import graphlearning as gl
558        import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
559        import sklearn.datasets as datasets
560
561        X,labels = datasets.make_moons(n_samples=500,noise=0.1)
562        W = gl.weightmatrix.knn(X,10,symmetrize=False)
563
564        train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=5)
565        train_labels = labels[train_ind]
566
567        model = gl.ssl.poisson(W, solver='gradient_descent')
568        pred_labels = model.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels)
569
570        accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, labels, train_ind)   
571        print("Accuracy: %.2f%%"%accuracy)
572
573        plt.scatter(X[:,0],X[:,1], c=pred_labels)
574        plt.scatter(X[train_ind,0],X[train_ind,1], c='r')
575        plt.show()
576        ```
577
578        Reference
579        ---------
580        [1] J. Calder, B. Cook, M. Thorpe, D. Slepcev. [Poisson Learning: Graph Based Semi-Supervised
581        Learning at Very Low Label Rates.](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v119/calder20a.html), 
582        Proceedings of the 37th International Conference on Machine Learning, PMLR 119:1306-1316, 2020.
583        """
584        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
585        if solver not in ['conjugate_gradient', 'spectral', 'gradient_descent']:
586            sys.exit("Invalid Poisson solver")
587        self.solver = solver
588        self.p = p
589        if p != 1:
590            self.solver = 'spectral'
591        self.use_cuda = use_cuda
592        self.min_iter = min_iter
593        self.max_iter = max_iter
594        self.tol = tol
595        self.spectral_cutoff = spectral_cutoff
596
597        #Setup accuracy filename
598        fname = '_poisson' 
599        if self.p != 1:
600            fname += '_p%.2f'%p
601        if self.solver == 'spectral':
602            fname += '_N%d'%self.spectral_cutoff
603            self.requries_eig = True
604        self.accuracy_filename = fname
605
606        #Setup Algorithm name
607        self.name = 'Poisson Learning'
608
609    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
610
611        n = self.graph.num_nodes
612        unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
613        k = len(unique_labels)
614        
615        #Zero out diagonal for faster convergence
616        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
617        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
618        G = graph.graph(W)
619
620        #Poisson source term
621        onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
622        source = np.zeros((n, onehot.shape[1]))
623        source[train_ind] = onehot - np.mean(onehot, axis=0)
624        
625        if self.solver == 'conjugate_gradient':  #Conjugate gradient solver
626
627            L = G.laplacian(normalization='normalized')
628            D = G.degree_matrix(p=-0.5)
629            u = utils.conjgrad(L, D*source, tol=self.tol)
630            u = D*u
631
632        elif self.solver == "gradient_descent":
633
634            #Setup matrices
635            D = G.degree_matrix(p=-1)
636            P = D*W.transpose()
637            Db = D*source
638
639            #Invariant distribution
640            v = np.zeros(n)
641            v[train_ind]=1
642            v = v/np.sum(v)
643            deg = G.degree_vector()
644            vinf = deg/np.sum(deg)
645            RW = W.transpose()*D
646            u = np.zeros((n,k))
647
648            #Number of iterations
649            T = 0
650            if self.use_cuda:
651
652                import torch 
653
654                Pt = utils.torch_sparse(P).cuda()
655                ut = torch.from_numpy(u).float().cuda()
656                Dbt = torch.from_numpy(Db).float().cuda()
657
658                while (T < self.min_iter or np.max(np.absolute(v-vinf)) > 1/n) and (T < self.max_iter):
659                    ut = torch.sparse.addmm(Dbt,Pt,ut)
660                    v = RW*v
661                    T = T + 1
662
663                #Transfer to CPU and convert to numpy
664                u = ut.cpu().numpy()
665
666            else: #Use CPU
667
668                while (T < self.min_iter or np.max(np.absolute(v-vinf)) > 1/n) and (T < self.max_iter):
669                    u = Db + P*u
670                    v = RW*v
671                    T = T + 1
672
673                    #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
674                    if all_labels is not None:
675                        self.prob = u
676                        labels = self.predict()
677                        acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
678                        print('%d,Accuracy = %.2f'%(T,acc))
679                
680        #Use spectral solver
681        elif self.solver == 'spectral':
682
683            vals, vecs = G.eigen_decomp(normalization='randomwalk', k=self.spectral_cutoff+1)
684            V = vecs[:,1:]
685            vals = vals[1:]
686            if self.p != 1:
687                vals = vals**self.p
688            L = sparse.spdiags(1/vals, 0, self.spectral_cutoff, self.spectral_cutoff)
689            u = V@(L@(V.T@source))
690
691        else:
692            sys.exit("Invalid Poisson solver " + self.solver)
693
694        return u

Poisson Learning

Semi-supervised learning via the solution of the Poisson equation [L^p u = \sum_{j=1}^m \delta_j(y_j - \overline{y})^T,] where (L=D-W) is the combinatorial graph Laplacian, (y_j) are the label vectors, (\overline{y} = \frac{1}{m}\sum_{i=1}^m y_j) is the average label vector, (m) is the number of training points, and (\delta_j) are standard basis vectors. See the reference for more details.

Implements 3 different solvers, spectral, gradient_descent, and conjugate_gradient. GPU acceleration is available for gradient descent. See [1] for details.

Parameters
  • W (numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None): Weight matrix representing the graph.
  • class_priors (numpy array (optional), default=None): Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of nodes in each class.
  • solver ({'spectral', 'conjugate_gradient', 'gradient_descent'} (optional), default='conjugate_gradient'): Choice of solver for Poisson learning.
  • p (int (optional), default=1): Power for Laplacian, can be any positive real number. Solver will default to 'spectral' if p!=1.
  • use_cuda (bool (optional), default=False): Whether to use GPU acceleration for gradient descent solver.
  • min_iter (int (optional), default=50): Minimum number of iterations of gradient descent before checking stopping condition.
  • max_iter (int (optional), default=1000): Maximum number of iterations of gradient descent.
  • tol (float (optional), default=1e-3): Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
  • spectral_cutoff (int (optional), default=10): Number of eigenvectors to use for spectral solver.
Examples

Poisson learning works on directed (i.e., nonsymmetric) graphs with the gradient descent solver: poisson_directed.py.

import numpy as np
import graphlearning as gl
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import sklearn.datasets as datasets

X,labels = datasets.make_moons(n_samples=500,noise=0.1)
W = gl.weightmatrix.knn(X,10,symmetrize=False)

train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=5)
train_labels = labels[train_ind]

model = gl.ssl.poisson(W, solver='gradient_descent')
pred_labels = model.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels)

accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, labels, train_ind)   
print("Accuracy: %.2f%%"%accuracy)

plt.scatter(X[:,0],X[:,1], c=pred_labels)
plt.scatter(X[train_ind,0],X[train_ind,1], c='r')
plt.show()

775    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
776
777        #Short forms
778        Ns = self.Ns
779        mu = self.mu
780        T = self.T
781        use_cuda = self.use_cuda
782
783        n = self.graph.num_nodes
784        unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
785        k = len(unique_labels)
786
787        #Zero out diagonal for faster convergence
788        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
789        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
790        G = graph.graph(W)
791        
792        #Poisson source term
793        onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
794        source = np.zeros((n, onehot.shape[1]))
795        source[train_ind] = onehot - np.mean(onehot, axis=0)
796
797        #Initialize via Poisson learning
798        labels = self.poisson_model.fit_predict(train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=all_labels)
799        u = utils.labels_to_onehot(labels)
800
801        #Time step for stability
802        dt = 1/np.max(G.degree_vector())
803
804        #Precompute some things
805        P = sparse.identity(n) - dt*G.laplacian()
806        Db = mu*dt*source
807
808        if use_cuda:
809            import torch
810            Pt = utils.torch_sparse(P).cuda()
811            Dbt = torch.from_numpy(Db).float().cuda()
812
813        for i in range(T):
814
815            #Heat equation step
816            if use_cuda:
817
818                #Put on GPU and run heat equation
819                ut = torch.from_numpy(u).float().cuda()
820                for j in range(Ns):
821                    ut = torch.sparse.addmm(Dbt,Pt,ut)
822
823                #Put back on CPU
824                u = ut.cpu().numpy()
825             
826            else: #Use CPU 
827                for j in range(Ns):
828                    u = P*u + Db
829
830            #Projection step
831            self.prob = u
832            labels = self.volume_label_projection()
833            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(labels)
834
835            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
836            if all_labels is not None:
837                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
838                print('%d, Accuracy = %.2f'%(i,acc))
839
840        return u

PoissonMBO

Semi-supervised learning via Poisson MBO method [1]. class_priors must be provided.

Parameters
  • W (numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None): Weight matrix representing the graph.
  • class_priors (numpy array (optional), default=None): Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class).
  • solver ({'spectral', 'conjugate_gradient', 'gradient_descent'} (optional), default='conjugate_gradient'): Choice of solver for Poisson learning.
  • use_cuda (bool (optional), default=False): Whether to use GPU acceleration for gradient descent solver.
  • min_iter (int (optional), default=50): Minimum number of iterations of gradient descent before checking stopping condition.
  • max_iter (int (optional), default=1000): Maximum number of iterations of gradient descent.
  • tol (float (optional), default=1e-3): Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
  • spectral_cutoff (int (optional), default=10): Number of eigenvectors to use for spectral solver.
  • Ns (int (optional), default=40): Number of inner iterations in PoissonMBO.
  • mu (float (optional), default=1): Fidelity parameter.
  • T (int (optional), default=20): Number of MBO iterations.
Example

Running PoissonMBO on MNIST at 1 label per class: poisson_mbo.py.

import graphlearning as gl

labels = gl.datasets.load('mnist', labels_only=True)
W = gl.weightmatrix.knn('mnist', 10, metric='vae')

num_train_per_class = 1
train_ind = gl.trainsets.generate(labels, rate=num_train_per_class)
train_labels = labels[train_ind]

class_priors = gl.utils.class_priors(labels)
model = gl.ssl.poisson_mbo(W, class_priors)
pred_labels = model.fit_predict(train_ind,train_labels,all_labels=labels)

accuracy = gl.ssl.ssl_accuracy(labels,pred_labels,train_ind)
print(model.name + ': %.2f%%'%accuracy)
Reference

[1] J. Calder, B. Cook, M. Thorpe, D. Slepcev. Poisson Learning: Graph Based Semi-Supervised Learning at Very Low Label Rates., Proceedings of the 37th International Conference on Machine Learning, PMLR 119:1306-1316, 2020.

class volume_mbo(ssl): 
842class volume_mbo(ssl):
843    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, temperature=0.1, volume_constraint=0.5):
844        """Volume MBO
845        ===================
846
847        Semi-supervised learning with the VolumeMBO method [1]. class_priors must be provided.
848
849        Parameters
850        ----------
851        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
852            Weight matrix representing the graph.
853        class_priors : numpy array
854            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). 
855        temperature : float (optional), default=0.1
856            Temperature for volume constrained MBO.
857        volume_constraint : float (optional), default=0.5
858            The number of points in each class is constrained to be a mulitple \\(\\lambda\\) of the true
859            class size, where 
860            \\[ \\text{volume_constraint} \\leq \\lambda \\leq 2-\\text{volume_constraint}.\\]
861            Setting `volume_constraint=1` yields the tightest constraint.
862
863        References
864        ----------
865        [1] M. Jacobs, E. Merkurjev, and S. Esedoḡlu. [Auction dynamics: A volume constrained MBO scheme.](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0021999117308033?casa_token=kNahPd2vu50AAAAA:uJQYQVnmMBV_oL0CG1UcOIulY4vhclMGTztm-jjAzy9Lns7rtoOnKs4iyvLOjKXaHU-D6qrQJT4) Journal of Computational Physics 354:288-310, 2018. 
866        """
867        super().__init__(W, None)
868
869        if class_priors is None:
870            sys.exit("Class priors must be provided for Volume MBO.")
871        self.class_counts = (self.graph.num_nodes*class_priors).astype(int)
872        self.temperature = temperature
873        self.volume_constraint = volume_constraint
874
875        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
876        self.accuracy_filename = '_volume_mbo_temp_%.2f_vol_%.2f'%(temperature,volume_constraint)
877        self.name = 'Volume MBO (T=%.2f, V=%.2f)'%(temperature,volume_constraint)
878
879
880    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
881
882        #Import c extensions
883        from . import cextensions
884
885        n = self.graph.num_nodes
886
887        #Set diagonal entries to zero
888        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
889        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
890        G = graph.graph(W)
891
892        #Set up graph for C-code
893        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
894        u = np.zeros((n,))
895        WI,WJ,WV = sparse.find(W)
896
897        #Type casting and memory blocking
898        u = np.ascontiguousarray(u,dtype=np.int32)
899        WI = np.ascontiguousarray(WI,dtype=np.int32)
900        WJ = np.ascontiguousarray(WJ,dtype=np.int32)
901        WV = np.ascontiguousarray(WV,dtype=np.float32)
902        train_ind = np.ascontiguousarray(train_ind,dtype=np.int32)
903        train_labels = np.ascontiguousarray(train_labels,dtype=np.int32)
904        ClassCounts = np.ascontiguousarray(self.class_counts,dtype=np.int32)
905
906        cextensions.volume_mbo(u,WI,WJ,WV,train_ind,train_labels,ClassCounts,k,1.0,self.temperature,self.volume_constraint)
907
908        #Set given labels and convert to vector format
909        u[train_ind] = train_labels
910        u = utils.labels_to_onehot(u)
911        return u

Volume MBO

Semi-supervised learning with the VolumeMBO method [1]. class_priors must be provided.

Parameters

class multiclass_mbo(ssl): 
 913class multiclass_mbo(ssl):
 914    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, Ns=6, T=10, dt=0.15, mu=50, num_eig=50):
 915        """Multiclass MBO
 916        ===================
 917
 918        Semi-supervised learning via the Multiclass MBO method [1].
 919
 920        Parameters
 921        ----------
 922        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
 923            Weight matrix representing the graph.
 924        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
 925            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
 926            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
 927            nodes in each class.
 928        Ns : int (optional), default=6
 929            Number of inner iterations.
 930        T : int (optional), default=10
 931            Number of outer iterations.
 932        dt : float (optional), default=0.15
 933            Time step.
 934        mu : float (optional), default=50
 935            Fidelity penalty.
 936        num_eig : int (optional), default=300
 937            Number of eigenvectors.
 938        
 939        References
 940        ---------
 941        [1] C. Garcia-Cardona, E. Merkurjev, A.L. Bertozzi, A. Flenner, and A.G. Percus. [Multiclass data segmentation using diffuse interface methods on graphs.](http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.743.9516&rep=rep1&type=pdf) IEEE transactions on pattern analysis and machine intelligence, 36(8), 1600-1613, 2014.
 942        """
 943        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
 944
 945        self.Ns = Ns
 946        self.T = T
 947        self.dt = dt
 948        self.mu = mu
 949        self.num_eig = num_eig
 950        self.requires_eig = True
 951
 952        #Setup accuracy filename
 953        self.accuracy_filename = '_multiclass_mbo_Ns_%d_T_%d_dt_%.3f_mu_%.2f'%(Ns,T,dt,mu)
 954        self.name = 'Multiclass MBO'
 955
 956
 957    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
 958
 959        #Shorten names
 960        Ns = self.Ns
 961        T = self.T
 962        dt = self.dt
 963        mu = self.mu
 964        num_eig = self.num_eig
 965
 966        #Basic parameters
 967        n = self.graph.num_nodes
 968        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
 969
 970        #Spectral decomposition
 971        eigvals, X = self.graph.eigen_decomp(normalization='normalized', k=self.num_eig)
 972
 973        #Form matrices
 974        V = np.diag(1/(1 + (dt/Ns)*eigvals)) 
 975        Y = X@V
 976        Xt = np.transpose(X)
 977
 978        #Random initial labeling
 979        u = np.random.rand(k,n)
 980        u = utils.labels_to_onehot(np.argmax(u,axis=0)).T
 981        u[:,train_ind] = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels).T
 982
 983        #Indicator of train_ind
 984        J = np.zeros(n,)
 985        K = np.zeros(n,)
 986        J[train_ind] = 1
 987        K[train_ind] = train_labels
 988        K = utils.labels_to_onehot(K).T
 989
 990        for i in range(T):
 991            #Diffusion step
 992            for s in range(Ns):
 993                Z = (u - (dt/Ns)*mu*J*(u - K))@Y
 994                u = Z@Xt
 995                
 996            #Projection step
 997            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(np.argmax(u,axis=0)).T
 998
 999            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1000            if all_labels is not None:
1001                self.prob = u.T
1002                labels = self.predict()
1003                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1004                print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1005
1006        return u.T

class modularity_mbo(ssl): 
1008class modularity_mbo(ssl):
1009    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, gamma=0.5, epsilon=1, lamb=1, T=20, Ns=5):
1010        """Modularity MBO
1011        ===================
1012
1013        Semi-supervised learning via the Modularity MBO method [1].
1014
1015        Parameters
1016        ----------
1017        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1018            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1019        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1020            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1021            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1022            nodes in each class.
1023        gamma : float (optional), default=0.5
1024            Parameter in algorithm.
1025        epsilon : float (optional), default=1
1026            Parameter in algorithm.
1027        lamb : float (optional), default=1
1028            Parameter in algorithm.
1029        T : int (optional), default=20
1030            Number of outer iterations.
1031        Ns : int (optional), default=5
1032            Number of inner iterations.
1033        
1034        References
1035        ---------
1036        [1] Z.M. Boyd, E. Bae, X.C. Tai, and A.L. Bertozzi. [Simplified energy landscape for modularity using total variation.](https://publications.ffi.no/nb/item/asset/dspace:4288/1619750.pdf) SIAM Journal on Applied Mathematics, 78(5), 2439-2464, 2018.
1037        """
1038        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1039
1040        self.gamma = gamma
1041        self.epsilon = epsilon
1042        self.lamb = lamb
1043        self.requires_eig = True
1044        self.T = T
1045        self.Ns = Ns
1046
1047        #Setup accuracy filename
1048        self.accuracy_filename = '_modularity_mbo_gamma_%.2f_epsilon_%.2f_lamb_%.2f'%(gamma,epsilon,lamb)
1049        self.name = 'Modularity MBO'
1050
1051    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1052
1053        #Short form
1054        gamma = self.gamma
1055        eps = self.epsilon
1056        lamb = self.lamb
1057        T = self.T
1058        Ns = self.Ns
1059
1060        #One-hot initialization
1061        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1062        num_classes = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1063        train_onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1064        u = np.zeros((n,num_classes))
1065        u[train_ind,:] = train_onehot
1066
1067        #Spectral decomposition
1068        num_eig = 5*num_classes
1069        D, V = self.graph.eigen_decomp(normalization='combinatorial', k=num_eig, gamma=gamma)
1070
1071        #Time step selection
1072        deg = self.graph.degree_vector()
1073        dtlow = 0.15/((gamma+1)*np.max(deg))
1074        dthigh = np.log(np.linalg.norm(u)/eps)/D[0]
1075        dt = np.sqrt(dtlow*dthigh)
1076
1077        #Diffusion matrix
1078        P = sparse.spdiags(np.exp(-D*dt),0,num_eig,num_eig)@V.T
1079
1080        #Main MBO iterations
1081        for i in range(T):
1082
1083            #Diffusion 
1084            u = V@(P@u)
1085
1086            #Training labels
1087            if lamb > 0:
1088                for _ in range(Ns):
1089                    u[train_ind,:] -= (dt/Ns)*lamb*(u[train_ind,:] - train_onehot)
1090
1091            #Threshold to labels
1092            labels = np.argmax(u,axis=1)
1093            
1094            #Convert to 1-hot vectors
1095            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(labels)
1096
1097            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1098            if all_labels is not None:
1099                self.prob = u
1100                labels = self.predict()
1101                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1102                print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1103
1104        return u

class laplace(ssl): 
1107class laplace(ssl):
1108    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, X=None, reweighting='none', normalization='combinatorial', 
1109                 tau=0, order=1, mean_shift=False, tol=1e-5, alpha=2, zeta=1e7, r=0.1):
1110        """Laplace Learning
1111        ===================
1112
1113        Semi-supervised learning via the solution of the Laplace equation
1114        \\[\\tau u_j + L^m u_j = 0, \\ \\ j \\geq m+1,\\]
1115        subject to \\(u_j = y_j\\) for \\(j=1,\\dots,m\\), where \\(L=D-W\\) is the 
1116        combinatorial graph Laplacian and \\(y_j\\) for \\(j=1,\\dots,m\\) are the 
1117        label vectors. Default order is m=1, and m > 1 corresponds to higher order Laplace Learning.
1118
1119        The original method was introduced in [1]. This class also implements reweighting 
1120        schemes `poisson` proposed in [2], `wnll` proposed in [3], and `properly`, proposed in [4].
1121        If `properly` is selected, the user must additionally provide the data features `X`.
1122
1123        Parameters
1124        ----------
1125        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1126            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1127        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1128            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1129            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1130            nodes in each class.
1131        X : numpy array (optional)
1132            Data features, used to construct the graph. This is required for the `properly` weighted 
1133            graph Laplacian method.
1134        normalization : {'combinatorial','randomwalk','normalized'} (optional), defualt='combinatorial'
1135            Normalization for the graph Laplacian.
1136        reweighting : {'none', 'wnll', 'poisson', 'properly'} (optional), default='none'
1137            Reweighting scheme for low label rate problems. If 'properly' is selected, the user
1138            must supply the data features `X`.
1139        tau : float or numpy array (optional), default=0
1140            Zeroth order term in Laplace equation. Can be a scalar or vector.
1141        order : integer (optional), default=1
1142            Power m for higher order Laplace learning. Currently only integers are allowed. 
1143        mean_shift : bool (optional), default=False
1144            Whether to shift output to mean zero.
1145        tol : float (optional), default=1e-5
1146            Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
1147        alpha : float (optional), default=2
1148            Parameter for `properly` reweighting.
1149        zeta : float (optional), default=1e7
1150            Parameter for `properly` reweighting.
1151        r : float (optional), default=0.1
1152            Radius for `properly` reweighting.
1153
1154        References
1155        ---------
1156        [1] X. Zhu, Z. Ghahramani, and J. D. Lafferty. [Semi-supervised learning using gaussian fields 
1157        and harmonic functions.](https://www.aaai.org/Papers/ICML/2003/ICML03-118.pdf) Proceedings 
1158        of the 20th International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML-03), 2003.
1159
1160        [2] J. Calder, B. Cook, M. Thorpe, D. Slepcev. [Poisson Learning: Graph Based Semi-Supervised
1161        Learning at Very Low Label Rates.](http://proceedings.mlr.press/v119/calder20a.html), 
1162        Proceedings of the 37th International Conference on Machine Learning, PMLR 119:1306-1316, 2020.
1163
1164        [3] Z. Shi, S. Osher, and W. Zhu. [Weighted nonlocal laplacian on interpolation from sparse data.](https://idp.springer.com/authorize/casa?redirect_uri=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10915-017-0421-z&casa_token=33Z7gqJy3mMAAAAA:iMO0pGmpn_qf5PioVIGocSRq_p4CDm-KNOQhgIC1uvqG9pWlZ6t7I-IZtSJfocFDEHCdMpK8j7Fx1XbzDQ)
1165        Journal of Scientific Computing 73.2 (2017): 1164-1177.
1166
1167        [4] J. Calder, D. Slepčev. [Properly-weighted graph Laplacian for semi-supervised learning.](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00245-019-09637-3) Applied mathematics & optimization (2019): 1-49.
1168        """
1169        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1170
1171        self.reweighting = reweighting
1172        self.normalization = normalization
1173        self.mean_shift = mean_shift
1174        self.tol = tol
1175        self.order = order
1176        self.X = X
1177
1178        #Set up tau
1179        if type(tau) in [float,int]:
1180            self.tau = np.ones(self.graph.num_nodes)*tau
1181        elif type(tau) is np.ndarray:
1182            self.tau = tau
1183
1184        #Setup accuracy filename
1185        fname = '_laplace' 
1186        self.name = 'Laplace Learning'
1187        if self.reweighting != 'none':
1188            fname += '_' + self.reweighting
1189            self.name += ': ' + self.reweighting + ' reweighted'
1190        if self.normalization != 'combinatorial':
1191            fname += '_' + self.normalization
1192            self.name += ' ' + self.normalization
1193        if self.mean_shift:
1194            fname += '_meanshift'
1195            self.name += ' with meanshift'
1196        if self.order > 1:
1197            self.name += ' order %d'%int(self.order)
1198        if np.max(self.tau) > 0:
1199            fname += '_tau_%.3f'%np.max(self.tau)
1200            self.name += ' tau=%.3f'%np.max(self.tau)
1201
1202        self.accuracy_filename = fname
1203
1204
1205    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1206
1207        #Reweighting
1208        if self.reweighting == 'none':
1209            G = self.graph
1210        else:
1211            W = self.graph.reweight(train_ind, method=self.reweighting, normalization=self.normalization, X=self.X)
1212            #W = self.graph.reweight(train_ind, method=self.reweighting, X=self.X)
1213            G = graph.graph(W)
1214
1215        #Get some attributes
1216        n = G.num_nodes
1217        unique_labels = np.unique(train_labels)
1218        k = len(unique_labels)
1219        
1220        #tau + Graph Laplacian and one-hot labels
1221        L = sparse.spdiags(self.tau, 0, G.num_nodes, G.num_nodes) + G.laplacian(normalization=self.normalization)
1222        if self.order > 1:
1223            Lpow = L*L
1224            if self.order > 2:
1225                for i in range(2,self.order):
1226                    Lpow = L*Lpow
1227            L = Lpow
1228        F = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1229
1230        #Locations of unlabeled points
1231        idx = np.full((n,), True, dtype=bool)
1232        idx[train_ind] = False
1233
1234        #Right hand side
1235        b = -L[:,train_ind]*F
1236        b = b[idx,:]
1237
1238        #Left hand side matrix
1239        A = L[idx,:]
1240        A = A[:,idx]
1241
1242        #Preconditioner
1243        m = A.shape[0]
1244        M = A.diagonal()
1245        M = sparse.spdiags(1/np.sqrt(M+1e-10),0,m,m).tocsr()
1246       
1247        #Conjugate gradient solver
1248        v = utils.conjgrad(M*A*M, M*b, tol=self.tol)
1249        v = M*v
1250
1251        #Add labels back into array
1252        u = np.zeros((n,k))
1253        u[idx,:] = v
1254        u[train_ind,:] = F
1255
1256        #Mean shift
1257        if self.mean_shift:
1258            u -= np.mean(u,axis=0)
1259
1260        return u

Laplace Learning

Semi-supervised learning via the solution of the Laplace equation [\tau u_j + L^m u_j = 0, \ \ j \geq m+1,] subject to (u_j = y_j) for (j=1,\dots,m), where (L=D-W) is the combinatorial graph Laplacian and (y_j) for (j=1,\dots,m) are the label vectors. Default order is m=1, and m > 1 corresponds to higher order Laplace Learning.

The original method was introduced in [1]. This class also implements reweighting schemes poisson proposed in [2], wnll proposed in [3], and properly, proposed in [4]. If properly is selected, the user must additionally provide the data features X.

Parameters
  • W (numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None): Weight matrix representing the graph.
  • class_priors (numpy array (optional), default=None): Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of nodes in each class.
  • X (numpy array (optional)): Data features, used to construct the graph. This is required for the properly weighted graph Laplacian method.
  • normalization ({'combinatorial','randomwalk','normalized'} (optional), defualt='combinatorial'): Normalization for the graph Laplacian.
  • reweighting ({'none', 'wnll', 'poisson', 'properly'} (optional), default='none'): Reweighting scheme for low label rate problems. If 'properly' is selected, the user must supply the data features X.
  • tau (float or numpy array (optional), default=0): Zeroth order term in Laplace equation. Can be a scalar or vector.
  • order (integer (optional), default=1): Power m for higher order Laplace learning. Currently only integers are allowed.
  • mean_shift (bool (optional), default=False): Whether to shift output to mean zero.
  • tol (float (optional), default=1e-5): Tolerance for conjugate gradient solver.
  • alpha (float (optional), default=2): Parameter for properly reweighting.
  • zeta (float (optional), default=1e7): Parameter for properly reweighting.
  • r (float (optional), default=0.1): Radius for properly reweighting.
References

[1] X. Zhu, Z. Ghahramani, and J. D. Lafferty. Semi-supervised learning using gaussian fields and harmonic functions. Proceedings of the 20th International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML-03), 2003.

[2] J. Calder, B. Cook, M. Thorpe, D. Slepcev. Poisson Learning: Graph Based Semi-Supervised Learning at Very Low Label Rates., Proceedings of the 37th International Conference on Machine Learning, PMLR 119:1306-1316, 2020.

[3] Z. Shi, S. Osher, and W. Zhu. Weighted nonlocal laplacian on interpolation from sparse data. Journal of Scientific Computing 73.2 (2017): 1164-1177.

[4] J. Calder, D. Slepčev. Properly-weighted graph Laplacian for semi-supervised learning. Applied mathematics & optimization (2019): 1-49.

class dynamic_label_propagation(ssl): 
1262class dynamic_label_propagation(ssl):
1263    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, alpha=0.05, lam=0.1, T=2):
1264        """Dynamic Label Propagation
1265        ===================
1266
1267        Semi-supervised learning via dynamic label propagation [1].
1268
1269        Parameters
1270        ----------
1271        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1272            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1273        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1274            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1275            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1276            nodes in each class.
1277        alpha : float (optional), default=0.05
1278            Value of parameter \\(\\alpha\\).
1279        lam : float (optional), default=0.1
1280            Value of parameter \\(\\lambda\\).
1281        T : int (optional), default=2
1282            Number of iterations.
1283
1284        References
1285        ---------
1286        [1] B. Wang, Z. Tu, and J.K. Tsotsos. [Dynamic label propagation for semi-supervised multi-class multi-label classification.](https://openaccess.thecvf.com/content_iccv_2013/html/Wang_Dynamic_Label_Propagation_2013_ICCV_paper.html) Proceedings of the IEEE international conference on computer vision. 2013.
1287        """
1288        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1289
1290        self.alpha = alpha
1291        self.lam = lam
1292        self.T = T
1293
1294        self.accuracy_filename = '_dynamic_label_propagation'
1295        self.name = 'Dynamic Label Propagation'
1296 
1297
1298    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1299
1300        #Short forms
1301        alpha = self.alpha
1302        lam = self.lam
1303        T = self.T
1304        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1305        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1306
1307        #Zero out diagonal 
1308        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
1309        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
1310        G = graph.graph(W)
1311        
1312        #Labels to vector and correct position
1313        K = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1314        u = np.zeros((n,k))
1315        u[train_ind,:] = K 
1316      
1317        if n > 5000:
1318            print("Cannot use Dynamic Label Propagation on large datasets.")
1319        else:
1320            #Setup matrices
1321            Id = sparse.identity(n) 
1322            D = G.degree_matrix(p=-1)
1323            P = D*W
1324            P = np.array(P.todense())
1325            Pt = np.copy(P)
1326
1327            for i in range(T):
1328                v = P@u
1329                u = Pt@u
1330                u[train_ind,:] = K
1331                Pt = P@Pt@np.transpose(P) + alpha*v@np.transpose(v) + lam*Id
1332
1333                #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1334                if all_labels is not None:
1335                    self.prob = np.array(u)
1336                    labels = self.predict()
1337                    acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1338                    print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1339
1340            u = np.array(u)
1341
1342        return u

Dynamic Label Propagation

  • class_priors (numpy array (optional), default=None): Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of nodes in each class.

class centered_kernel(ssl): 
1345class centered_kernel(ssl):
1346    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, tol=1e-10, power_it=100, alpha=1.05):
1347        """Centered Kernel Method
1348        ===================
1349
1350        Semi-supervised learning via the centered kernel method of [1].
1351
1352        Parameters
1353        ----------
1354        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1355            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1356        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1357            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1358            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1359            nodes in each class.
1360        tol : float (optional), default=1e-10
1361            Tolerance to solve equation.
1362        power_it : int (optional), default=100
1363            Number of power iterations to find largest eigenvalue.
1364        alpha : float (optional), default = 1.05
1365            Value of \\(\\alpha\\) as a fraction of largest eigenvalue.
1366
1367        References
1368        ---------
1369        [1] X. Mai and R. Couillet. [Random matrix-inspired improved semi-supervised learning on graphs.](https://romaincouillet.hebfree.org/docs/conf/SSL_ICML18.pdf) International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.
1370        """
1371        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1372
1373        self.tol = tol
1374        self.power_it = power_it
1375        self.alpha = alpha
1376
1377        self.accuracy_filename = '_centered_kernel'
1378        self.name = 'Centered Kernel'
1379        
1380    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1381
1382        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1383        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1384
1385        #Zero diagonal
1386        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
1387        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
1388
1389        #Indicator of train_ind
1390        K = np.zeros((n,k))
1391        K[train_ind] = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1392        
1393        #Center labels
1394        K[train_ind,:] -= np.sum(K,axis=0)/len(train_ind)
1395
1396        #Initialization
1397        u = np.copy(K)
1398        v = np.ones((n,1))
1399        vt = np.ones((1,n))
1400
1401        e = np.random.rand(n,1)
1402        for i in range(self.power_it):
1403            y = W*(e -  (1/n)*v@(vt@e))
1404            w = y - (1/n)*v@(vt@y) #=Ae
1405            l = abs(np.transpose(e)@w/(np.transpose(e)@e))
1406            e = w/np.linalg.norm(w)
1407
1408        #Number of iterations
1409        alpha = self.alpha * l
1410        err = 1
1411        while err > self.tol:
1412            y = W*(u -  (1/n)*v@(vt@u))
1413            w = (1/alpha)*(y - (1/n)*v@(vt@y)) - u #Laplacian
1414            w[train_ind,:] = 0
1415            err = np.max(np.absolute(w))
1416            u = u + w
1417
1418            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1419            if all_labels is not None:
1420                self.prob = u
1421                labels = self.predict()
1422                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1423                print('Accuracy = %.2f'%acc)
1424            
1425        return u

1365            Value of \\(\\alpha\\) as a fraction of largest eigenvalue.
1366

1368        ---------
1369        [1] X. Mai and R. Couillet. [Random matrix-inspired improved semi-supervised learning on graphs.](https://romaincouillet.hebfree.org/docs/conf/SSL_ICML18.pdf) International Conference on Machine Learning. 2018.

1375        self.alpha = alpha
1376
1377        self.accuracy_filename = '_centered_kernel'
1378        self.name = 'Centered Kernel'

Centered Kernel Method

Semi-supervised learning via the centered kernel method of [1].

Parameters
  • W (numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None): Weight matrix representing the graph.
  • class_priors (numpy array (optional), default=None): Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of nodes in each class.
  • tol (float (optional), default=1e-10): Tolerance to solve equation.
  • power_it (int (optional), default=100): Number of power iterations to find largest eigenvalue.
  • alpha (float (optional), default = 1.05): Value of (\alpha) as a fraction of largest eigenvalue.
References

class sparse_label_propagation(ssl): 
1428class sparse_label_propagation(ssl):
1429    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, T=100):
1430        """Sparse Label Propagation
1431        ===================
1432
1433        Semi-supervised learning via the sparse label propagation method of [1].
1434
1435        Parameters
1436        ----------
1437        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1438            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1439        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1440            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1441            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1442            nodes in each class.
1443        T : int (optional), default=100
1444            Number of iterations
1445
1446        References
1447        ---------
1448        [1] A. Jung, A.O. Hero III, A. Mara, and S. Jahromi. [Semi-supervised learning via sparse label propagation.](https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.01414) arXiv:1612.01414, 2016.
1449        """
1450        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1451
1452        self.T = T
1453        self.accuracy_filename = '_sparse_label_propagation'
1454        self.name = 'Sparse LP'
1455        
1456    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1457
1458        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1459        k = len(np.unique(train_labels))
1460
1461        #Sparse matrix with ones in all entries
1462        B = self.graph.adjacency()
1463
1464        #Construct matrix 1/2W and 1/deg
1465        lam = 2*self.graph.weight_matrix - (1-1e-10)*B
1466        lam = -lam.log1p()
1467        lam = lam.expm1() + B
1468        Id = sparse.identity(n) 
1469        gamma = self.graph.degree_matrix(p=-1)
1470
1471        #Random initial labeling
1472        u = np.zeros((k,n))
1473
1474        #Indicator of train_ind
1475        one_hot_labels = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels).T
1476
1477        #Initialization
1478        Y = list()
1479        for j in range(k):
1480            Gu = self.graph.gradient(u[j,:], weighted=True)
1481            Y.append(Gu)
1482
1483        #Main loop for sparse label propagation
1484        for i in range(self.T):
1485
1486            u_prev = np.copy(u)
1487            #Compute div
1488            for j in range(k):
1489                div = 2*self.graph.divergence(Y[j])
1490                u[j,:] = u_prev[j,:] - gamma*div
1491                u[j,train_ind] = one_hot_labels[j,:]  #Set labels
1492                u_tilde = 2*u[j,:] - u_prev[j,:]
1493
1494                Gu = -self.graph.gradient(u_tilde, weighted=True)
1495                Y[j] = Y[j] + Gu.multiply(lam)
1496                ind1 = B.multiply(abs(Y[j])>1)
1497                ind2 = B - ind1
1498                Y[j] = ind1.multiply(Y[j].sign()) + ind2.multiply(Y[j])
1499
1500            #Compute accuracy if all labels are provided
1501            if all_labels is not None:
1502                self.prob = u.T
1503                labels = self.predict()
1504                acc = ssl_accuracy(labels,all_labels,train_ind)
1505                print('%d,Accuracy = %.2f'%(i,acc))
1506 
1507        return u.T

class graph_nearest_neighbor(ssl): 
1510class graph_nearest_neighbor(ssl):
1511    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, D=None, alpha=1):
1512        """Graph nearest neighbor classifier
1513        ===================
1514
1515        Semi-supervised learning by graph (geodesic) nearest neighbor classifier. The 
1516        graph geodesic distance is defined by
1517        \\[ d_{ij} = \\min_p \\sum_{k=1}^M w_{p_k,p_{k+1}},\\]
1518        where the minimum is over paths \\(p\\) connecting nodes \\(i\\) and \\(j\\). The label
1519        returned for each testing point is the label of the closest labeled point.
1520
1521        Parameters
1522        ----------
1523        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1524            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1525        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1526            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1527            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1528            nodes in each class.
1529        D : numpy array or scipy sparse matrix (optional)
1530            (n,n) Distance matrix, giving distances between neighbors. If provided,
1531            this is used to construct a knn density estimator for reweighting the eikonal equation.
1532        alpha : float (optional), default=1
1533            Reweighting exponent.
1534        """
1535        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1536
1537
1538        self.alpha = alpha
1539
1540        if class_priors is not None:
1541            self.onevsrest = True
1542            self.similarity = False
1543
1544        #Cannot reweight if distance matrix not provided
1545        if D is None:
1546            self.f = 1
1547        else:
1548            d = D.max(axis=1).toarray().flatten() #distance to furtherest neighbor
1549            self.f = (d/np.max(d))**alpha
1550
1551        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1552        self.accuracy_filename = '_graph_nearest_neighbor_alpha%.2f'%(self.alpha) 
1553        self.name = 'Graph NN (alpha=%.2f)'%(self.alpha)
1554
1555    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1556
1557        if self.onevsrest:
1558            u = self.graph.dijkstra(train_ind[train_labels], bdy_val=0, f=self.f)
1559        else: 
1560            _,l = self.graph.dijkstra(train_ind, bdy_val=np.zeros_like(train_ind), f=self.f, return_cp=True)
1561            u = np.zeros(l.shape)
1562            u[train_ind] = train_labels
1563            u = utils.labels_to_onehot(u[l])
1564
1565        return u

Graph nearest neighbor classifier

Semi-supervised learning by graph (geodesic) nearest neighbor classifier. The graph geodesic distance is defined by [ d_{ij} = \min_p \sum_{k=1}^M w_{p_k,p_{k+1}},] where the minimum is over paths (p) connecting nodes (i) and (j). The label returned for each testing point is the label of the closest labeled point.

Parameters
  • W (numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None): Weight matrix representing the graph.
  • class_priors (numpy array (optional), default=None): Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of nodes in each class.
  • D (numpy array or scipy sparse matrix (optional)): (n,n) Distance matrix, giving distances between neighbors. If provided, this is used to construct a knn density estimator for reweighting the eikonal equation.
  • alpha (float (optional), default=1): Reweighting exponent.
