1567class amle(ssl):
1568    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, tol=1e-3, max_num_it=1e5, weighted=False, prog=False):
1569        """AMLE learning
1570        ===================
1571
1572        Semi-supervised learning by the Absolutely Minimal Lipschitz Extension (AMLE). This is the same as
1573        p-Laplace with \\(p=\\infty\\), except that AMLE has an option `weighted=False` that significantly 
1574        accelerates the solver.
1575
1576        Parameters
1577        ----------
1578        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1579            (n,n) Weight matrix representing the graph.
1580        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1581            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1582            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1583            nodes in each class.
1584        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
1585            Tolerance with which to solve the equation.
1586        max_num_it : int (optional), default=1e5
1587            Maximum number of iterations
1588        weighted : bool (optional), default=False
1589            When False, the graph is converted to a 0/1 adjacency matrix, which affords a much faster solver.
1590        prog : bool (optional), default=False
1591            Whether to print progress information.
1592        """
1593        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1594
1595        self.tol = tol
1596        self.max_num_it = max_num_it
1597        self.weighted = weighted
1598        self.prog = prog
1599        self.onevsrest = True
1600
1601        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1602        self.accuracy_filename = '_amle'
1603        if not self.weighted:
1604            self.accuracy_filename += '_unweighted'
1605        self.name = 'AMLE'
1606
1607
1608    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1609
1610        u = self.graph.amle(train_ind, train_labels, tol=self.tol, max_num_it=self.max_num_it, 
1611                                                     weighted=self.weighted, prog=self.prog)
1612        return u

1616        """Graph p-eikonal classifier
1617        ===================
1618
1619        Semi-supervised learning by via the solution of the graph `graph.peikonal` equation.
1620

1622        ----------

1641            Number of bisection iterations for solver.
1642        eps_ball_graph : bool (optional), default=False

1657        if D is None:
1658            if eps_ball_graph:
1659                d = self.graph.degree_vector()
1660                self.f = (d/np.max(d))**(-alpha)
1661            else:
1662                self.f = 1
1663        else:
1664            d = D.max(axis=1).toarray().flatten() #distance to furtherest neighbor
1665            self.f = (d/np.max(d))**alpha

1673

1675                                                tol=self.tol, num_bisection_it=self.num_bisection_it, prog=False)
1676        return u

1680    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, p=10, max_num_it=1e6, tol=1e-1, fast=True):
1681        """Graph p-laplace classifier
1682        ===================
1683
1684        Semi-supervised learning by via the solution of the game-theoretic p-Laplace equation [1].
1685
1686        Parameters
1687        ----------
1688        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1689            (n,n) Weight matrix representing the graph.
1690        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1691            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1692            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1693            nodes in each class.
1694        p : float (optional), default=10
1695            Value of p in the p-Laplace equation (\\( 2 \\leq p \\leq \\infty\\).
1696        max_num_it : int (optional), default=1e5
1697            Maximum number of iterations
1698        tol : float (optional), default=1e-3
1699            Tolerance with which to solve the equation.
1700        fast : bool (optional), default=True
1701            Whether to use constant \\(w_{ij}=1\\) weights for the infinity-Laplacian
1702            which allows a faster algorithm to be used.
1703
1704        References
1705        ----------
1706        [1] M. Flores Rios, J. Calder, and G. Lerman. [Algorithms for \\( \\ell_p\\)-based semi-supervised learning on graphs.](https://arxiv.org/abs/1901.05031) arXiv:1901.05031, 2019.
1707        """
1708        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1709
1710        self.p = p
1711        self.max_num_it = max_num_it
1712        self.tol = tol
1713        self.onevsrest = True
1714        self.fast = fast
1715
1716        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1717        self.accuracy_filename = '_plaplace_p%.2f'%self.p 
1718        self.name = 'p-Laplace (p=%.2f)'%self.p
1719
1720
1721    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1722        u = self.graph.plaplace(train_ind, train_labels, self.p, max_num_it=self.max_num_it, tol=self.tol,fast=self.fast)
1723        return u

Graph p-laplace classifier

Semi-supervised learning by via the solution of the game-theoretic p-Laplace equation [1].

Parameters
  • W (numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None): (n,n) Weight matrix representing the graph.
  • class_priors (numpy array (optional), default=None): Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of nodes in each class.
  • p (float (optional), default=10): Value of p in the p-Laplace equation (( 2 \leq p \leq \infty).
  • max_num_it (int (optional), default=1e5): Maximum number of iterations
  • tol (float (optional), default=1e-3): Tolerance with which to solve the equation.
  • fast (bool (optional), default=True): Whether to use constant (w_{ij}=1) weights for the infinity-Laplacian which allows a faster algorithm to be used.
References

[1] M. Flores Rios, J. Calder, and G. Lerman. Algorithms for ( \ell_p)-based semi-supervised learning on graphs. arXiv:1901.05031, 2019.

class randomwalk(ssl): 
1727class randomwalk(ssl):
1728    def __init__(self, W=None, class_priors=None, alpha=0.95):
1729        """Lazy random walk classification
1730        ===================
1731
1732        Add description.
1733
1734        The original method was introduced in [1], and can be interpreted as a lazy random walk. 
1735
1736        Parameters
1737        ----------
1738        W : numpy array, scipy sparse matrix, or graphlearning graph object (optional), default=None
1739            Weight matrix representing the graph.
1740        class_priors : numpy array (optional), default=None
1741            Class priors (fraction of data belonging to each class). If provided, the predict function
1742            will attempt to automatic balance the label predictions to predict the correct number of
1743            nodes in each class.
1744        alpha : float (optional), default=0.95
1745            Parameter in model.
1746
1747        References
1748        ---------
1749        [1] D. Zhou and B. Schölkopf. [Learning from labeled and unlabeled data using random walks.](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-540-28649-3_29) Joint Pattern Recognition Symposium. 
1750        Springer, Berlin, Heidelberg, 2004.
1751        """
1752        super().__init__(W, class_priors)
1753
1754        self.alpha = alpha
1755
1756        #Setup accuracy filename and model name
1757        self.accuracy_filename = '_randomwalk' 
1758        self.name = 'Lazy Random Walks'
1759
1760
1761    def _fit(self, train_ind, train_labels, all_labels=None):
1762        
1763        alpha = self.alpha
1764
1765        #Zero diagonals
1766        n = self.graph.num_nodes
1767        W = self.graph.weight_matrix
1768        W = W - sparse.spdiags(W.diagonal(),0,n,n)
1769        G = graph.graph(W)
1770
1771        #Construct Laplacian matrix
1772        L = (1-alpha)*sparse.identity(n) + alpha*G.laplacian(normalization='normalized')
1773
1774        #Preconditioner
1775        m = L.shape[0]
1776        M = L.diagonal()
1777        M = sparse.spdiags(1/np.sqrt(M+1e-10),0,m,m).tocsr()
1778       
1779        #Right hand side
1780        onehot = utils.labels_to_onehot(train_labels)
1781        Y = np.zeros((n, onehot.shape[1]))
1782        Y[train_ind,:] = onehot
1783
1784        #Conjugate gradient solver
1785        u = utils.conjgrad(M*L*M, M*Y, tol=1e-6)
1786        u = M*u
1787
1788        return u

def ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, true_labels, train_ind): 
1790def ssl_accuracy(pred_labels, true_labels, train_ind):   
1791    """SSL Accuacy
1792    ======
1793
1794    Accuracy for semi-supervised graph learning, taking care to remove training set.
1795    NOTE: Any true labels with negative values will be removed from 
1796    accuracy computation.
1797
1798    Parameters
1799    ----------
1800    pred_labels : numpy array, int
1801        Predicted labels
1802    true_labels : numpy array, int
1803        True labels
1804    train_ind : numpy array, int 
1805        Indices of training points, which will be removed from the accuracy computation.
1806
1807    Returns
1808    -------
1809    accuracy : float
1810        Accuracy as a number in [0,100].
1811    """
1812
1813        #Remove labeled data
1814    mask = np.ones(len(pred_labels),dtype=bool)
1815    if type(train_ind) != np.ndarray:
1816        print("Warning: ssl_accuracy has been updated and now requires the user to provide the indices of the labeled points, and not just the number of labels. Accuracy computation will be incorrect unless you update your code accordingly. See https://jwcalder.github.io/GraphLearning/ssl.html#two-moons-example")
1817    else:
1818        mask[train_ind]=False
1819
1820    pred_labels = pred_labels[mask]
1821    true_labels = true_labels[mask]
1822
1823    #Remove unlabeled nodes
1824    I = true_labels >=0
1825    pred_labels = pred_labels[I]
1826    true_labels = true_labels[I]
1827
1828    #Compute accuracy
1829    return 100*np.mean(pred_labels==true_labels)

SSL Accuacy

Accuracy for semi-supervised graph learning, taking care to remove training set. NOTE: Any true labels with negative values will be removed from accuracy computation.

Parameters
  • pred_labels (numpy array, int): Predicted labels
  • true_labels (numpy array, int): True labels
  • train_ind (numpy array, int): Indices of training points, which will be removed from the accuracy computation.
Returns
  • accuracy (float): Accuracy as a number in [0,100].

1834    """Accuracy Plot

1879        else:

1881                plt.loglog(num_train, acc_mean[:,0], styles[i], label=model.name)
1882            else:
1883                plt.plot(num_train, acc_mean[:,0], styles[i], label=model.name) #3rd argumnet=styles[i]
1884
1885        #If class priors were run as well
1886        if acc_mean.shape[1] > 1:
1887            i = (i+1)%7
1888            if errorbars:
1889                plt.errorbar(num_train, acc_mean[:,1], fmt=styles[i], yerr=acc_stddev[:,1], label=model.name+'+CP')
1890            else:
1891                if loglog:
1892                    plt.loglog(num_train, acc_mean[:,1], styles[i], label=model.name+'+CP')
1893                else:
1894                    plt.plot(num_train, acc_mean[:,1], styles[i], label=model.name+'+CP') #3rd argumnet=styles[i]
1895
1896     
1897    plt.xlabel('Number of labels',fontsize=label_fontsize)
1898    if testerror:
1899        plt.ylabel('Test error (%)',fontsize=label_fontsize)
1900        plt.legend(loc='upper right',fontsize=legend_fontsize)
1901    else:
1902        plt.ylabel('Accuracy (%)',fontsize=label_fontsize)
1903        plt.legend(loc='lower right',fontsize=legend_fontsize)
1904    if title is not None:
1905        plt.title(title)

1917    else:
1918        plt.show()

def accuracy_table( model_list, tag='', testerror=False, savefile='table.tex', title='', append=False, fontsize='small', small_caps=True, two_column=True): 
1920def accuracy_table(model_list, tag='', testerror=False, savefile='table.tex', title='', 
1921                               append=False, fontsize='small', small_caps=True, two_column=True):
1922    """Accuracy table
1923    ======
1924
1925    Creates a table of accuracy scores for experiments run with `ssl_trials` to be
1926    included in a LaTeX document.
1927
1928    Parameters
1929    ----------
1930    model_list : list of ssl objects
1931        Models to include in table.
1932    tag : str (optional), default=''
1933        An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
1934    testerror : bool (optional), default=False
1935        Show test error (instead of accuracy) in the table.
1936    savefile : str (optional), default='table.tex'
1937        Filename to save tex code for table.
1938    title : str (optional), default=''
1939        Title for table.
1940    append : bool (optional), default=False
1941        Whether to create a new tex file or append table to existing file.
1942    fontsize : str (optional), default='small'
1943        LaTeX font size.
1944    small_caps : bool (optional), default=True
1945        Whether to use small caps in LaTeX for table.
1946    two_column : bool (optional), default=True
1947        Whether the table will be in a two-column LaTeX document.
1948    """
1949
1950
1951    num_train,acc_mean,acc_stddev,num_trials = model_list[0].trials_statistics(tag=tag)
1952    m = len(num_train)
1953
1954    #Determine best algorithm at each label rate
1955    best = [None]*m
1956    class_priors_best = [False]*m
1957    best_score = [0]*m
1958    for i, model in enumerate(model_list):
1959        num_train,acc_mean,acc_stddev,num_trials = model.trials_statistics(tag=tag)
1960        for j in range(m):
1961            if acc_mean[j,0] > best_score[j]:
1962                best_score[j] = acc_mean[j,0]
1963                best[j] = i
1964
1965        #Check if class priors accuracy was included as well
1966        if acc_mean.shape[1] > 1:
1967            for j in range(m):
1968                if acc_mean[j,1] > best_score[j]:
1969                    best_score[j] = acc_mean[j,1]
1970                    class_priors_best[j] = True
1971                    best[j] = i
1972
1973    
1974    if append:
1975        f = open(savefile,"r")
1976        lines = f.readlines()
1977        f.close()
1978        f = open(savefile,"w")
1979        f.writelines([item for item in lines[:-1]])
1980    else:
1981        f = open(savefile,"w")
1982        f.write("\\documentclass{article}\n")
1983        f.write("\\usepackage[T1]{fontenc}\n")
1984        f.write("\\usepackage{booktabs}\n")
1985        f.write("\\usepackage[margin=1in]{geometry}\n")
1986        f.write("\\begin{document}\n")
1987
1988    f.write("\n\n\n")
1989    if two_column:
1990        f.write("\\begin{table*}[t!]\n")
1991    else:
1992        f.write("\\begin{table}[t!]\n")
1993    f.write("\\vspace{-3mm}\n")
1994    f.write("\\caption{"+title+": Average (standard deviation) classification accuracy over %d trials.}\n"%num_trials)
1995    f.write("\\vspace{-3mm}\n")
1996    f.write("\\label{tab:"+title+"}\n")
1997    f.write("\\vskip 0.15in\n")
1998    f.write("\\begin{center}\n")
1999    f.write("\\begin{"+fontsize+"}\n")
2000    if small_caps:
2001        f.write("\\begin{sc}\n")
2002    f.write("\\begin{tabular}{l")
2003    for i in range(m):
2004        f.write("l")
2005    f.write("}\n")
2006    f.write("\\toprule\n")
2007    f.write("\\# Labels")
2008    for i in range(m):
2009        f.write("&\\textbf{%d}"%int(num_train[i]))
2010    f.write("\\\\\n")
2011    f.write("\\midrule\n")
2012    i = 0
2013
2014    for i, model in enumerate(model_list):
2015        num_train,acc_mean,acc_stddev,num_trials = model.trials_statistics(tag=tag)
2016
2017        f.write(model.name.ljust(15))
2018        for j in range(m):
2019            if best[j] == i and not class_priors_best[j]: 
2020                f.write("&{\\bf %.1f"%acc_mean[j,0]+" (%.1f)}"%acc_stddev[j,0])
2021            else:
2022                f.write("&%.1f"%acc_mean[j,0]+" (%.1f)      "%acc_stddev[j,0])
2023        f.write("\\\\\n")
2024        
2025        #Check if class priors accuracy was included as well
2026        if acc_mean.shape[1] > 1:
2027            f.write((model.name+'+CP').ljust(15))
2028            for j in range(m):
2029                if best[j] == i and class_priors_best[j]: 
2030                    f.write("&{\\bf %.1f"%acc_mean[j,1]+" (%.1f)}"%acc_stddev[j,1])
2031                else:
2032                    f.write("&%.1f"%acc_mean[j,1]+" (%.1f)      "%acc_stddev[j,1])
2033            f.write("\\\\\n")
2034
2035    f.write("\\bottomrule\n")
2036    f.write("\\end{tabular}\n")
2037    if small_caps:
2038        f.write("\\end{sc}\n")
2039    f.write("\\end{"+fontsize+"}\n")
2040    f.write("\\end{center}\n")
2041    f.write("\\vskip -0.1in\n")
2042    if two_column:
2043        f.write("\\end{table*}")
2044    else:
2045        f.write("\\end{table}")
2046    f.write("\n\n\n")
2047    f.write("\\end{document}\n")
2048    f.close()

Accuracy table

Creates a table of accuracy scores for experiments run with ssl_trials to be included in a LaTeX document.

Parameters
  • model_list (list of ssl objects): Models to include in table.
  • tag (str (optional), default=''): An extra identifying tag to add to the accuracy filename.
  • testerror (bool (optional), default=False): Show test error (instead of accuracy) in the table.
  • savefile (str (optional), default='table.tex'): Filename to save tex code for table.
  • title (str (optional), default=''): Title for table.
  • append (bool (optional), default=False): Whether to create a new tex file or append table to existing file.
  • fontsize (str (optional), default='small'): LaTeX font size.
  • small_caps (bool (optional), default=True): Whether to use small caps in LaTeX for table.
  • two_column (bool (optional), default=True): Whether the table will be in a two-column LaTeX document.
